Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario. Miss L. J. Brunton, teacher at the Massett Indian Day School, advised some time ago that the number of toilets at the Massett School was not sufficient for the enrolled pupilage and as a result Mr. Indian Agent Phillips has submitted the attached letter and details of material and labour required in this connection. As the attendance at this school appears to average thirty boys and thirty girls, additional accommodation is necessary. If funds are available it is recommended that Mr. Phillips be authorized to proceed with the work at a cost of approximately $100.00. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C. Your File: 215-11-7653. With reference to your letter of the 7th of December, in respect to definite recommendations for the number of toilets for the Massett Indian Day school, I herewith submit for your approval estimate and quotation of materials for one three hole Toilet for the Girls and one Urinal for the Boys. The Girls toilet will have partitions and three separate doors with lids that fall down when not in use, the boys urinal will have one door. All the Materials for the above work can be purchased locally. B.T. Phillips, Indian Agent. 215-11-8691 Ottawa, February 13, 1945. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 70, Vancouver, B.C. I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to improving the toilets at the Massett School. You mention in your letter that approximately $100.00 will be required. In reviewing the correspondence which you forwarded, it appears to me that $97.54 is the estimated cost of the toilet for the girls and $55.68 for the boys. This would total $153.20, which expenditure is approved. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division. **STATEMENT** MASSETT, BC Department of Mines & Resources Indian Affairs Branch For Indian Day School-Masset, B.C. FORM No. I.A. 566 Voucher No. 286 Date March 29th, 1945 EDUCATION: Both the Massett and Skidegate Schools have been painted inside and outside, new wood shed, toilets, and urinal have been built (or nearly completed) at the Massett School. New wood shed and toilet have been built at the teachery and new furniture and alterations for the comfort of our teachers. At the Skidegate Reserve a new urinal is being built, and also a new fence is being built at the teachery; there is no doubt that the Indian schools are the best on the Islands; the Indians children of this Agency are very bright, and several are now attending superior schools here; the children are exceptionally good at Needle work, drawing, painting and very musical; the parents are very keen on giving their children a good education. We are not equipped for Manual training, but have a large class room for this purpose at the Massett school as soon as conditions permit an instructor for that work. Basket making also Slate Totem pole Carving was taught at both schools, but this was stopped at the beginning of the war; several Indian drawings and designs have been entered in a competition at the Stanford University, U.S.A.; we have not as yet heard the result of judges; I usually visit the Massett School three times a month and the Skidegate twice a month; Junior Red Cross work is being carried on at both schools. The Massett school has been adopted by the Sir James Barrie Imperial Daughters of the Empire, from which sporting goods etc., have been received for the pupils. B.B. Bertson I have your letter of April 12th with regard to janitor service at the Masset Indian Day School for acknowledgement. This building, although not new, is in fair condition and with minor repairs, additional equipment and a third teacher (kindergarten) could become one of the finest day schools in the district. In the near future, after the School Inspector's visit, I shall submit several suggestions with regard to these matters for consideration by the Department. The question at present is that of satisfactory janitor service. The man who has been engaged for this work has very poor vision and could not satisfactorily perform his duties. At present, due to rising operations and the small remuneration paid for such work, it has been impossible to engage another man. The teachers have taken over the duties for the balance of the term. However, it is not, in my estimation, fair to expect Day School Teachers to be burdened with janitor work in addition to their teaching and supervising duties. In a school of this type, janitor's duties should include lighting of fires each morning, sweeping, dusting, washing and oiling of floors when necessary, inspection and cleaning of outside toilets and general supervision of the upkeep of the building. It is obvious that no person will assume these duties for the remuneration offered of $12. monthly, which sum works out, on the basis of 21 teaching days per month, at fifty-seven cents per day. I would suggest, that since similar conditions exist at the S. Kidegate Indian Day School, where $10.00 monthly is paid, the entire janitor situation be revised with the object in mind of obtaining satisfactory janitor service for which a decent remuneration be paid. I would recommend that a man willing to assume the duties as mentioned be paid at minimum rate of $25.00 per month. No doubt if this were approved, suitable janitors could be obtained. The matter of ventilation has been investigated and several of the haws have been loosened to allow them to be opened providing proper ventilation. Advice and decision in the matter of janitor service will be appreciated. J.A. Findlay, Acting Indian Agent. Ottawa, May 29th, 1947. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Re: Transportation of Teachers - Massett School I have to refer to Mr. Neary's letter to Supt. Findlay, an undated copy of which was received here, regarding Queen Charlotte Agency voucher No. 494 in favour of Kurt Lindner General Store, covering transportation of the teachers at the Massett School from the white village to the Reserve, payment of which was not approved. The attached vouchers No. 606 and No. 7 apparently were submitted by Mr. Findlay prior to receipt of your letter and in view of all the circumstances I would ask that the Department's decision with regard to payment of these costs be reconsidered. In my letter of August 9th I pointed out that due to the condition of the teacherage at the Massett school it would be necessary to secure other accommodation for the teachers and recommended that the Department approve payment of rental for a house in Massett and transportation charges, which would amount to approximately $378 for the academic year. The alternative to this arrangement would have been an immediate expenditure of almost $1000 to make the teacherage building habitable. Rental of the house to be occupied by the teachers until such time as a new teacher's residence is erected was approved in Mr. Neary's letter of December 21st and in the absence of any advice to the contrary it was presumed that payment of transportation charges was also approved. TO ALL INDIAN AGENTS, ASSISTANTS, SUPERINTENDENTS, INSPECTORS, REGIONAL SUPERVISORS, AND THE INDIAN COMMISSIONER FOR BRITISH COLUMBIA. The Treasury Board, under date of July 30, 1948, T 352588 B, has issued a directive to Dominion Government Departments with reference to the transportation of employees at Government expense to and from their normal places of work of which the following excerpts are called to your attention: "The Treasury Board has considered the matter and they believe that in general, it is the responsibility of the employee to provide his own transportation. On the other hand, the board are aware that there are instances of an exceptional nature where the Government should accept the responsibility but they believe that all such classes or cases should be approved by the board before the necessary arrangements are made for transportation at the Government's expense. The Board directs: That, commencing April 1, 1949, transportation of employees to and from their place of employment at Government expense will require approval by the Treasury Board. "Note: Transportation of this nature whether or not it is properly authorized for 1948-49, will require the approval of the Board for continuation beyond April 1, 1949." The above ruling effects not only officials authorized to use their own personal car on Government business on a mileage basis but also those officials who customarily use Government owned cars to proceed from their homes to their office and return from their office to their homes. May each individual case in the above mentioned classes be reviewed and a full explanation be given if it is considered that the privilege should be continued. W. J. F. I am forwarding herewith a report received from Supt. Findlay regarding the earthquake experienced in the Queen Charlotte Islands area on August 21st and subsequent tremors. With regard to the damage sustained by the Day Schools, etc., I have authorized Supt. Findlay to have the necessary repairs carried out. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C. As advised during our telephone conversation yesterday and as perhaps you had already heard, the Queen Charlotte Islands experienced an earthquake of considerable force on Sunday night, August 21st. From radio reports it would appear that Masset was one spot which received about the heaviest shake-up. Fortunately no one was hurt, although several elderly persons are suffering from nervous reaction to the experience. I am not exaggerating in the slightest when I say that not only buildings and trees practically executed a dance but that the earth undulated in no uncertain fashion. Damage sustained was chiefly to brick chimneys, house foundations and furnishings. Many homes have lost entire china cabinets containing precious china. On the road leading from Masset to the North Beach several cracks in the road are to be seen and at one spot the bottom of the fissure cannot be seen nor can a small pebble dropped in be heard to hit bottom. Mrs. Findlay and I were out at the time of the heaviest quake and upon returning home found the place a regular shambles inside. Bookcases were knocked over, lamps toppled and smashed and pictures on the walls being at a 45 degree angle. Fortunately the kitchen oil range which had been left burning went out. I have the automatic shut off valve working so finely that any undue vibrations cause the flow of oil to be cut off. Damage reported to date so far as the Agency is concerned is as follows: 1. Masset School brick chimney damaged. 2. Skidegate School brick chimney down. 3. Crockery and dishes at Skidegate residence smashed. Both stoves there were moved causing the pipes to come out of the chimney. Damage caused by this has not yet been assessed. 4. Agency Office at Masset dropped 4 to 5 inches at one corner. The brick chimney is cracked and the flashing has parted from the roof. The entire building is sprung. Other parts of the Islands also suffered with 140,000 gallons of oil being lost at Cumshewa, when tanks fell into the Inlet. The local Navy Signal Building suffered $2000.00 damage when a huge 3 foot chimney crashed through the roof and down to the floor below. Since 9:05 p.m. on Sunday we have felt about a dozen more tremors, the last being about 8:30 last evening. Many people have not slept for two nights and particularly on Sunday night did residents roam the vicinity as the minor tremors continued throughout the night. As stated before we are fortunate that no one was hurt but even now a certain nervous tension still exists. Personally I hope there will be no repetition of the last weekend's excitement. J. A. Early this afternoon and subsequent to writing a letter regarding repairs at Masset School, a man working on the Agency residence roof called me back to examine the kitchen chimney. These had been examined after the major quake last month but seemingly the tremor this morning had finished what the first one had possibly started. I found bricks loose just above the flashing and the chimney swaying to the slightest touch. There was danger of the structure collapsing through the roof if a strong wind arose and we proceeded at once to dismantle the chimney brick by brick. This will necessitate the re-building of almost 5 feet of brick chimney. I shall have this done as soon as possible. J.A. Findlay, Superintendent, Queen Charlotte Agency Indian Affairs. Sir, I beg to acknowledge receipt of a letter, dated 12th June instant, in which I am informed "that the Department is unable to authorize this ($200.00) expenditure on teacher's residence as it has no funds available for this purpose." In a further letter, dated June 18th, I am informed: "When the Constable vacates the house you will be good enough to advise the Department as to what repairs are required." In reply permit me to state that, when the former teacher occupied the house, he kept three dogs and a cat therein. He used the woodshed for a chicken house, and did not improve the grounds, allowing the place to become overgrown with weeds. After he vacated, I fumigated the place, in company with the Constable, and Mr. Jessup washed out the floors and cleaned the walls. The first teacher, Mr. McCenkey, partly painted the residence, six years ago, but the roof was not painted, at any time. After Mr. Trainer left, it was plain that the building required attention, and the grounds also. Before a man and his wife could occupy the place—which Mr. Jessup did not do, up to the time I received your letter—it should be painted inside and outside; the woodshed should be whitewashed; a walk, from the gate to building, should be made, and the ground cleared of weeds and stumps. I considered that $200.00 would do this work, and make the place habitable. It is a good, little resi- The Asst. Deputy and Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont. Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6402, File 828-8, part 1) Sir, I beg to forward herewith statement of expenses, Vouchers Nos. 2678 to 2682 inclusive with accounts and return of labor, in connection with repairs to the Indian Agent's residence—occupied at present by the school teacher—at Massett. Voucher No. 2697 also enclosed. Whilst the sum of $500.00 was authorized for this work, it has cost altogether, $499.72. The work was inspected during my visit to Massett in November, and found very satisfactory. Besides re-shingling the house and renewing the gutter, part of the foundation was also renewed and other necessary repairs carried out. An account for labor, re-shingling, shingles and other repairs to the teacher's former residence, amounting to $19.00 is also enclosed. No authority was obtained for this work as the need or having it done was only known at the time or my visit to Massett. This house, which has two small rooms and kitchen, is situated about a mile from the village and for this reason is most unsuited as a residence for the teacher. It has not been occupied for some years and is falling rapidly into disrepair. As Mr. Mitchell had his men working at the school I thought it a favorable opportunity of having temporary repairs only carried out, until the matter could be taken up by the Department. As it may not again be used as a teacher's residence, I would recommend that it be sold for what it is worth—possibly $200.00, otherwise it is going to be a source of continual expense in keeping it in repair. Your obedient servant, Indian Agent. WEC, J.J. The Assistant Deputy and Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa. Letter of June 7th, 1926, on file 157-2-1 from L.H. Baillie, teacher of the Massett Indian Day School, points out the necessity of the following repairs: 1. Papering of residence. 2. Repairs to well. 3. Building a fence around lot on which agency building is located. As an alternative the teacher also suggests that it might be possible to secure from the Anglican Church, for the teacher's residence, a vacant house close to the school. On June 18th a letter was written Mr. Agent Collison requesting him to interview the teacher and discuss the above matters and report to the Department. It should be noted that the teacher is at present living in the residence formerly occupied by the Indian Agent at Massett. There is some question at the present time of re-appointing an Indian Agent and if so, the residence now occupied by Mr. Baillie will be required for the new Agent. 18/6/26. (RG 10, Volume 6402, File 828-8, part 1) PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA Sir, I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th ult., enclosing copy of Department's reply to a communication received from Mr. L.H. Baillie. Matters concerning which Mr. Baillie has written have already been brought to my attention, but principally on account of the large sum already expended on the Agency house this year, I did not consider it advisable to recommend further expenditures at the present time. With regard to the papering of the dwelling, as the rooms are well lined and neatly finished with dressed lumber, it does not seem necessary to have them papered, at least for the present. As to the condition of the well, there is no doubt that further repairs will be necessary, and a new water tank put in; an expenditure of $10 was authorized recently to put the well in temporary shape. Mr. Baillie states that if a fence was put around the house, he would be able to keep hens and cows. He has already been in residence a year and a half and to my knowledge has not attempted to do any manual labor, or take an interest in the appearance of the property whatsoever during that time, and I very much doubt whether he would ever have the energy to keep livestock, although it would mean much to his family. In view of the fact that a new agent is shortly to be appointed for the Islands and the Agency house now occupied temporarily by Mr. Baillie will likely be needed, I would suggest that any further expenditures be deferred until the new agent is appointed. In the event of Mr. Baillie having to vacate his present quarters arrangements might possibly be made to rent the mission house belonging to the Anglican Church at Massett for his use. The house in question has not been occupied for some time and is conveniently situated as a residence for the teacher. Should this suggestion meet with the Department's approval, I shall be glad to take the matter up with the Church authorities. Your obedient servant, The Assistant Deputy and Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa. WEC JJ. Ottawa, July 17, 1926. Sir: I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the request made by the teacher of the Massett Indian Day School to have certain repairs made to the agency house, which is being used by him as a residence, and for the providing of a water supply. In reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to incur any expense in the papering of the dwelling. Mr. Bailey, in a telegram to the Department dated the 10th instant, states that he can obtain a water tank - capacity 1500 gallons - at a price of $60, inclusive of the cost of installation. Please report whether you would recommend that this tank be purchased and if it would overcome the difficulty in providing for the supply of water. Until future arrangements are completed for the carrying on of the agency work at this point, the Department is not prepared to take any action in the renting of the mission house as a residence for the teacher. If it is necessary for the teacher to give up his present residence, we would have no objection to your taking this matter up with the church authorities, with a view to ascertaining if they would be prepared to rent the mission house and on what terms. We are not prepared to authorize the building of a fence around the lot on which the agency building is located. Your obedient servant, J. D. McLean, Asst. Deputy & Secretary. F. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B. C. Massey, B.C. Oct. 24, 1926. The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont. Dear Sir, A number of matters in connection with the school and my residence here have been referred to you. I have been advised at different times that you have asked Indian Agent Collin for a report, or (by him) that he has referred the whole matter back to the Department as an Indian Agent is to be appointed some day. I wrote Mr. Collin six weeks ago and have had no reply of any kind from him. A first toilet was provided at the house. A terra cotta pipe was put in as a drain fifteen years ago. A part of this has been clogged and the whole thing is therefore out of commission. I asked for immediate authority... to have the necessary repairs made or other suitable provision made. The department provided a cook stove and a heater when I came here two years ago. The driftwood, which is the only kind available, under the present arrangement of having the Indians supply fuel, is very hard to obtain. I have put in several claims, but the stoves are now completely done. It is very doubtful whether the top of the cookstove will hold up until a reply can be received from you. I cannot afford to buy stoves at this rate and I do not think the department can either. The yearly requirement of wood is 26 cords costing at present $160. A year ago last April Mr. Collison wrote me (when I had been here two or three months) asking for an estimate of the wood required for the year. I was not in a position to make a final estimate but stated that "a minimum of 16 cords would be required." In August of the same year I informed him verbally that 20 cords would be needed. No mention was made then of the fact that the department would have to authorize an increase. Last winter payment of certain vouchers for wood was delayed until after March 31st on the ground that the 16 cords authorized had been supplied. The letter informing me of the acceptance of my application advised me that "fuel would be provided." We do not want any, but it is well known that the kind of wood that is furnished here has no lasting qualities and the amount used is large. It has worked out as I finally estimated that 20 cords would At the year's requirement. Seven loads are therefore needed to complete the supply of wood necessary to March 31, 1927. It would be advisable, I think, if coal was provided, even if a limit of $8160 were made on the annual expenditure by the Department. The chief councillor, Alfred Adams, made the suggestion that arrangements should be made to get coal as no one wants to get wood. The water supply has never been properly attended to. The well which holds only a few days' water, owing to the condition of the cobbly, the well cannot be kept in use. There are a number of other matters that have not had attention, but the matter of stores, water, fuel and sanitary provision must have immediate attention. I would suggest that the department think over regarding the plan and whether or not they are prepared to make an allowance toward the purchase of stores and how much. It is agreeable to this course kindly advise by wire that the change to another kind of fuel has been authorized and authorize the expenditure of $56 to complete the fuel supply of 1925-26 and 1926-27. This is important as arrangements must be made to get new stores within a few days. Yours truly, Hamilton Baillie P.S. - All matters excepting that of the stores and the proposed change in fuel have been referred to Indian Agent Collison or various occasions without result. Nothing has been heard yet re stores or supplies to house that which I wrote months ago. OTTAWA, Nov. 4, 1926. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C. It is very doubtful if the top of the cook stove will hold up until a reply can be received from you." With reference to the fuel requirement, he states as follows: "The yearly requirement is 20 cords, costing at present $160. We do not waste any, but it is well known that the kind furnished here has no lasting qualities, and the amount used is large. It has worked out as I estimated that 20 cords would be the year's requirement. Seven more cords are, therefore, needed to complete the supply of wood necessary to March 31st, 1927." W. E. C. - Mr. - Mr. Baillie has suggested that coal be supplied in place of wood, but, owing to the cost in having this delivered, it is considered that as long as wood can be obtained, we would not be prepared to authorize the furnishing of coal. With reference to the water supply, he states that this has never been properly attended to, the water tank holds only a few days' water, and that, owing to the condition of the cribbing, the well cannot be kept in use. In this connection I would refer you to previous correspondence. With reference to the drain, he states that a flush toilet was provided at the house, a terra cotta pipe was put in as a drain fifteen years ago, a part of this drain has crumbled, and the whole thing is therefore out of commission. As requested in our telegram, the Department would like you to take immediate steps to have the work authorized carried out. Deputy and Secretary. Ottawa, November 5th, 1926. Sir: I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, drawing attention to the need of a new stove and heater for the use of the teacher's living quarters at the Massett Indian Day School, and also requesting that a further supply of fuel be furnished, that repairs required be made to the drain from the toilet at the residence, and that the water supply receive attention. In this connection I beg to inform you that we yesterday wired Mr. Agent Collison to purchase and forward a new stove and heater, to arrange for supplying the extra quantity of fuel required and for the repairs to the drain and water supply. With reference to the fuel, we are not prepared to authorize the supplying of coal owing to the cost of having same delivered at Massett. It is considered that as long as wood can be obtained it should be satisfactory. Your obedient servant, J. D. McLean, Asst. Deputy and Secretary. L. Hamilton Baillie, teacher of the Massett Indian Day School, that the Department purchase a quantity of furniture which he obtained and is using in the living quarters of himself and his family. I may say that, in cases where a teacher's residence is provided, a small quantity of furnishings is supplied, and, in this case, if you consider that the furniture which Mr. Baillie has on hand would be satisfactory for future use, I should be pleased if you would inform the Department whether you would recommend its purchase. March 9, 1927 The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont. Dear Sir, When I came here two years ago the Department provided the following furniture; two stoves, a kitchen table, four wood chairs, a bed and two linoleum rugs. It was necessary for me to buy an additional bed ($32.50), a table ($6.50), 4 wicker chairs ($50), 2 wood arm chairs ($8), linoleum ($30), an extra heater ($12.50), small table ($2). My income, as you know, has been $1050. It costs for groceries, meat, vegetables, milk, etc., about $75 per month. Owing to the fact that my wife has not been well, it has been necessary to have... some help in the house. This has cost about $15 per month. That is my income is $87.50 per month and my expenses, not including clothing, life insurance, medical fees, etc., are $90. I was able to make $125 during the summer of 1926, but nothing — 1925. Prospects are not good for earning much — 1927. Owing to their ill health and the necessity of procuring for them medical attention that cannot be had here, it will be necessary to send my wife and one of the children to Vancouver. As may be seen I have no surplus funds for this. Can the department take over the furniture, amounting to approximately $140, thus releasing the amount for a very necessary purpose. Yours truly, [Signature] Indian Affairs. Indian Agent Form No. 11 Ottawa, October 16, 1928. Reverend Sir: I have your letter of the 6th instant, nominating the services of Miss McQueen, of Vancouver, who has a first class professional certificate, as third teacher at the Massett Indian Day School. In reply I beg to confirm the following night telegram to you of today's date: "Department approves appointment Miss McQueen as third teacher, Massett School, from first proximo, with salary at rate one hundred dollars per month. You may purchase supplies for teachers' residence, as mentioned in your letter sixth instant." It is understood that Miss McQueen's services will only be required from the first of November, next, until approximately the end of April, 1929. You should notify her, in order that she can be at Massett in time to commence duties or about the first proximo. I am pleased to hear from you, later, as to Miss McQueen's Christian name and also the date upon which she begins duties. Full particulars should also be forwarded as to her qualifications, experience, etc. Relative to the supplies required for the use of the teachers' residence I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a bed, spring and mattress for the new teacher. It is noted you estimate the cost to be approximately $15.50. You may also arrange for the purchase of three small dressers for the teachers' bedrooms. It is noted that you estimate the cost of these to be $15 each. Further, you may purchase a wash tub for the use of the teachers. After these supplies have been delivered, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. Your obedient servant, J. D. McLean Asst. Deputy & Secretary. Rev. James Gillett, Indian Agent, Massett, B. C. Ottawa, October 2nd, 1926. Rev. Sir: I have your letter of the 13th instant, advising the Department that the furniture, stoves, etc., have been moved from the agency building to the mission house for the use of the teachers of the Massett Indian Day School, and that the teachers are now comfortably settled therein. It is noted that several rooms in the mission house require renovating. The department will approve of having the bedrooms and kitchen repapered and kalsomined. We note that the paper, kalsomine and paint will cost approximately $25, and the labour about $30. You may also arrange to have the carpenter work carried out in repairing the floor and boards around the base of the house. The Department will also approve of installing a hot water tank, with pipe and fittings, to be connected with the bath tub in the house. The cost of the tank, labour, etc., should not exceed the estimate stated in your letter. All expense in the above work should be kept as low as possible, and when the work is completed to your satisfaction, please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and for the labour in having the work performed. You should have the above authorized work carried out at an early date. Your obedient servant, Rev. J. Gillett, Indian Agent, Massett, B.C. J. D. McLean, Asst. Deputy and Secretary. Ottawa, August 17th, 1925. Rev. Sir: I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to your moving into the agency building at Massett, which is at present being used by the teachers as a residence, and obtaining a lease of the parsonage from the Anglican Church authorities to provide accommodation for the teachers of the Massett Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that the department agrees with you that it would be advisable for you to live on the Reserve, occupying the agency building. You may arrange with His Lordship Bishop Rix for the rental of the parsonage to be used as a residence by the teachers. We would agree to pay rental for the parsonage at the rate of $15 per month, which will be paid upon receipt of a voucher, in duplicate, properly certified by you, from time to time. The amount now allowed for the rental of the house at New Massett can be taken off the pay list and, as stated, vouchers should be forwarded for the payment of the rental of the parsonage for the use of the teachers. I shall be pleased if you will make the necessary arrangements to obtain the parsonage and have the present furniture in the agency house moved into the parsonage before the teachers arrive in September. It is hoped that there is sufficient furnishings on hand for the teachers. If not, a requisition should be forwarded for any further supplies required, giving an estimate of the cost of the various items. Any expenses that may be necessary in the moving of the furniture to the parsonage will be paid upon receipt of a certified voucher from you. Your obedient servant, A. F. MacKenzie, Acting Ass't. Dear Sir, Would you be good enough to inform this Department if there is a fixed daily rate of pay for the employment of British Columbia Land Surveyors in the Prince Rupert district. Secretary of the British Columbia Land Surveyors Corporation, Victoria, B.C. Dear Sir:- With reference to your enquiry concerning the rates of pay of B.C. Land Surveyors in the Prince Rupert District, I beg to inform you that our By-law concerning this matter reads as follows: "That for the keeping of discipline and for guarding the professional honour of the British Columbia Land Surveyors (under Section 6, Clause (a) of the Act), the following day rate be adopted, viz., $25 and upwards plus all expenses." The only exception to this rule is where the British Columbia Government employ Land Surveyors for the summer season when they pay them a daily rate of $15 a day from the date of leaving town to the date of returning, Sundays included, together with all expenses and a small monthly camp equipment allowance. My Corporation would very much appreciate it if on work of a few days duration only the Department of the Interior would pay our ordinary daily rate of $25. MURPHY, With reference to the attached memorandum to Council, I wish to inform you that there is at Massett a very successful Indian day school. The enrolment last year reached as high as 65 and the average attendance for the December quarter was 48. Two female teachers are employed. In September, 1929, it was necessary to secure new quarters for the teachers. In the past they had lived in the agency residence, but as I wished to have them all live on the reserve, other accommodation had to be found for the teachers. The mission house belonging to the Anglican Bishop of Caledonia was available and it was rented at a cost of $180 per annum. His Lordship Bishop Rix believed that the low rental freed the church authorities from making repairs on the property. I consider it advisable for the Department to have ownership of the building. $180 rental per annum is, I believe, amply worth the property can be purchased for approximately $1,000. Further we can make expenditures on the building, when necessary, without hesitation, when ownership is in the Crown. I am enclosing a picture of the house in question. It is 36 ft. by 22 ft. and was erected in 1919. It contains a sitting room, a dining room, kitchen, pantry, laundry, three bedrooms and a bathroom. The chimney is brick and there is an open fireplace in the sitting room. Duncan C. Scott Deputy Superintendent General. Dear Sir, In your letter No. 157-2-8, of Aug. 11th, I was given permission to have a hot water tank installed in the teachers' residence at Massett. On investigation I have found that the outside water tank is too low to give sufficient pressure for a hot water tank inside. It would necessitate raising the outside tank, so I have postponed this work until next year, as it would cost more than I had estimated. Your obedient servant, Indian Agent. At the Massett Reserve which I visited about seven times I inspected the painting of the School and building of the new wood shed, also inspected the teachers for repairs to be done during the holidays. I interviewed some of the Councillors at different times, the Chief being away fishing, so that a Council meeting was not held. I also visited several homes and the Cannery which is now canning Salmon. The clam operation this year was not so good, but this was due chiefly to bad weather; however, the last two weeks around 5,000 cases of Salmon have been packed, and the supply of fish is plentiful. The majority of the men folk are out fishing in Area No. 2, and they are expecting a big run of Humps in the Massett Inlet very soon as they have been "spotted" outside North Island coming this way. B.T. Phillips, Indian Agent Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C. Fray as teachers at the Massett Indian Day School, this office received numerous complaints with respect to the condition of the teacherage, lack of furnishings, water supply etc., culminating in both teachers threatening to resign at Christmas if the conditions complained of were not remedied. Mr. Indian Agent Phillips being absent on holiday leave during September it was not possible to immediately obtain a report on the situation but from information now to hand it would appear that although conditions were somewhat exaggerated, the teachers have some grounds for complaint. (RG 10, Volume 6402, File 828-8, part 2) PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA Queen Charlotte Agency Massett, B.C. June 24th, 1947. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C. I wish to submit the following report concerning the teachers at the Massett Indian Day School. 1. School closed on Friday June 20th, in order that Mrs. Conroy and Miss Donnison might reach Victoria in time for the opening of Summer School. The school days June 23-27 had been made up by teaching extra days as shown on the Senior teachers Quarterly Report. 2. Both teachers informed me that it was not their intention to return to Massett next term. They were told to submit their written resignations if they had so decided. Despite their assurances that this would be done, all reports were turned in but no resignations received. I am writing Mrs. Conroy at Victoria requesting such. 3. From reports received, it would appear that the teachers residence had been entered once during the year in their absence and personal property scattered throughout the house. On Sunday, June 15th the teachers were awakened at 5 a.m. by a noise seemingly caused by someone prowling near windows. They scared off the intruder and at the same time recognized him. To Mrs. Conroy's surprise it was one of the school boys in her room, Horace Yeltatzie. The boy, later in the day, gave no explanation for his actions and his teacher reports him to be one of the quietest of pupils though extremely slow and backward in his work. Inquiries made in the village reveal the fact that the boy is considered "queer". He has never been known to take anything or molest anyone, but has a habit of continually prowling around houses at all hours. His mother of course defends him as being innocent of all intent to do mischief. Members of the Council, the B.C.Provincial Policeman and I all talked to Horace and it is to be hoped that it had some effect. After careful consideration and by request of Mrs. Conroy, no further action was taken. 4. On Thursday morning, June 19th I received an urgent phone call from Miss Donnison to come to the school. Upon my arr- ival I was told the following facts. "At six o'clock that morning, while sleeping in bed Miss Donnison received a terrific blow on the left side of the face. Awakening suddenly both she and Mrs. Conroy saw a man's figure leap down the stairs and disappear. It would appear that he broke into the house through the back door, entered the bed- room, delivered the blow and ran escaping by the back door. The action happened so quickly and both teachers were in such a daze that they could not identify the intruder. The only description they could give was that he had a brown coat and ran in bare feet. Immediately I investigated the possibility of the previous intruder having returned (the boy Horace was at school) but there was no evidence of the boy being out of bed at that time of morning on the 19th. Calling a Council Meeting, and having the B.C. Provincial Constable bring in two young men who had been suspected of prowling around houses I inquired further. The two young men established satisfactory alibis and were allowed to go. The Council members are greatly concerned over the affair and when I stressed the seriousness of the situation and pointed out the fact that the reputation of the Massett Reserve was at stake, they took the responsibility of attempting to discover by their own methods, the identity of the intruder. They realize too, that such a sit- uation might make it extremely difficult to obtain teachers for their children. If it had been the intention of Mrs. Conroy to possibly return for another term, this incident must certainly influence her against doing so! It was most unfortunate that such a thing should happen at all, but taking place as it did on the eve of their dep- arture from Massett was a deplorable climax to their term's work. Needless to say, they were extremely nervous about remaining in the residence on Thursday night, June 19th and I instructed them to spend that night in the hotel at New Massett. enclose a voucher covering hotel charges, and under the circumstances recommend that it be passed for payment. Investigation into the matter is still being carried on, and it is my intention, should the culprit be apprehended to press charges, if necessary. Upon further developments, if any, a report will be submitted to the Commissioner. When the teachers' resignations are received they shall be forwarded, and in the meantime, advice as to filling the vacancies will be appreciated. J.A. Findlay, A/Indian Agent. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont. I am enclosing for your information a copy of Mr. Acting Indian Agent Findley's letter of June 24th and voucher No. 234 referred to therein. The incidents described by Mr. Findley are a repetition of similar occurrences on the Massett Reserve with respect to teachers and are much regretted. Mr. Findley has taken the only action possible under the circumstances and the arrangements made with respect to hotel accommodation made for the teachers on their last night at Massett were advisable. The Agent's report regarding further developments, if any, will be forwarded when received and in the meantime I would recommend payment of the enclosed voucher. [Signature] T. W. This expenditure was authorized by Departmental Letter, File No. dated Voucher No. 359 Date: July 27, 1948 I have to report the following with regard to living accommodation at Masset for three Masset Indian Day School Teachers. 1. The house which was mentioned during our recent conversation is not available. Despite the fact that the owner only uses it occasionally, he will not rent under any circumstances. 2. I have obtained what I consider still better accommodations and which I am certain will prove to be completely satisfactory. Mr. and Mrs. David Hutton, park owners in the local sawmill, have the largest home in the vicinity. Since they are alone in the house, they have, for some time, been considering renting a portion of the building. They have decided to move to the upper floor which is being turned into a self-contained flat and have signified their willingness to rent the lower half of the house. This consists of kitchen, combined living-room and dining-room and two bedrooms, one of which is sufficiently large to contain two beds. These rooms are completely furnished. The kitchen has a sawdust burning range, a wood heater in the living-room and a heater in the large bedroom. This space is ample and the house is most comfortable. 3. Mr. Hutton is willing to lease this for a period of ten months starting September 1st, 1946 at a monthly rental of $45.00. This is slightly higher than the figure I quoted for the other house, but in view of the fact that it will include light (electric), fuel, linen and necessary dishes, plus all the comforts of a private home, the rental asked is, in my opinion, very fair. Should I have been able to obtain the other house, fuel and light (lamp) would have to be supplied in addition to furnishing dishes, etc., and it is not equipped with any modern conveniences. 4. I consider that we are very fortunate in being able to obtain such accommodation for the next school year, and comfortable living quarters may help in holding teachers here. 5. Mr. Ratten has signed the attached lease and I strongly urge that it be approved and signed by the proper official of the Department. In view of distance and infrequent mail service I am also enclosing a voucher covering payment for rental for four months as per the agreement. 6. Your letter of July 15th, File 11-112 refers to your proposed recommendation that the Department provide transportation for the teachers to and from the Reserve at an approximate cost of $3.00 per day. I have made arrangements with a local taxi driver to provide such service at $2.00 per day. He will call for the teachers at 8:30 A.M. each school day and at a set hour each afternoon for the return trip. I trust these arrangements are satisfactory and that the lease will be approved. I would appreciate confirmation by wire as soon as you have ascertained the reaction of the Department. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Federal Bldg., Vancouver, B.C. I have your telegram regarding construction of a teachers residence at Masset and submit the following as a preliminary report. 1. I am in accordance with the proposal of constructing a new teachers residence at Masset as soon as possible but there are several factors which must be considered very carefully. 2. A house similar to that being erected at Skidegate would most definitely not be suitable for Masset. 3. On May 7th, I compiled and submitted a table showing the possible number of school age children during the next several years. These figures would tend to indicate that the Masset School building will have to be enlarged and in due time four or five teachers appointed. Should this develop, there is no reason why Junior High Grades should not be taught. This would most likely mean that a male Principal and three or four other teachers would eventually form the teaching staff at Masset Indian Day School. 4. Although the problem of increased school accommodation can be considered later, the above facts must be considered when a decision is being reached, as to the size of the proposed house. It would be a most regrettable error if the Department insisted on constructing a residence now to accommodate two or three teachers without taking into consideration the question of future requirements as a result of the increasing Indian population at Masset. 5. A three bedroom house would suffice at the present time, if the Department understands that in the event of a larger teaching staff being employed added accommodation would have to be provided. Should, for instance, in the near future, this school develop into a Junior High, and a male principal, plus three or four teachers... be employed, a small separate cottage could be built to accommodate the principal, whether he be single or married, and the residence proposed now occupied by the remainder of the staff. I cannot stress this point too strongly, since it is my conviction that it will not be very long before increased school facilities will have to be provided at Masset. 6. Should it be decided to proceed now the following points are important. (a) Site: The existing residence should be dismantled and the new structure erected on the same site. In this respect I would recommend that the old building be allotted to a Masset Indian for dismantling and removal. (b) House: Model "K" as shown in the Multi-flex booklet, 40' x 28' provides for 3 bedrooms. Model "H" is not satisfactory despite having 100 sq. ft. more floor space. This latter model has a hall way which, if all doors are closed, would be in practically complete darkness. In this part of the country, all light possible is needed. (c) Basement: There should be a full basement. This will mean extra labor in excavation but for reasons of heating, storage space, etc. the basement should be included. (d) Heating: Furnace, automatic oil burning, should be installed. Oil-burning kitchen range. Fireplace should also be included. (e) Plumbing: Masset has no water system and it is proposed that a concrete cistern be built in the basement to hold rain water. Inside plumbing to be installed with complete pressure pump system and service tank. Septic tank for drainage. (f) Lighting: There is no power in Masset Reserve and an 800 Watt A.C. 60 cycle Power Plant should be installed. This will supply light and power for pumping water from cistern to service tank. (g) Furnishings: The house would need new furnishings, with the exceptions of dinette set and 2 beds which are the only items in good condition. Linoleum and window blinds, etc. will have to be provided. It is obvious that this cannot be built for $5000.00, and a quick estimate of all materials required would indicate a cost of approximately $6500.00, including an allowance for freight charges. I cannot see where the house, as described above can be erected for much less than $10,000.00. I would not like to undertake supervision of the construction unless it was understood that funds up to that amount were available. The question arises as to whether the same building could be erected for less by purchasing all frame materials at the local sawmill. Freight charges on this would be saved, but all other items including windows, doors, interior lining, etc., would have to be shipped in. Time would actually be saved by the erection of a pre-fab building since these items are included in the house purchase. Mr. Phillips will undertake the work on a labor contract basis but I cannot furnish any definite estimate of this until a decision is reached by the Department. Should a decision to build now be definitely reached, I strongly urge that the following points be thoroughly considered. 1. Model "R" house. 2. The problem of future accommodation be kept in mind. 3. Construction be made on the basis of points (a) - (g). 4. Funds up to $10,000.00 be available if needed. J.A. Findlay, Superintendent, Queen Charlotte Agency. MEMORANDUM TO: The Indian Commissioner for B.C. FROM: The District School Inspector. Re: Masset Day School Teacherage I refer to Mr. Findlay's letter of September 11th concerning the above. It is noted that Mr. Findlay anticipates a very rapid growth in the enrolment at the above mentioned school and has recommended that provision be made for the construction of a three room block at this school and at the same time keep in mind the possibility of the employment of an additional three teachers. At the present time we have some 25 pupils enrolled at the Masset Junior, Senior High School and it seems that the Board is sympathetic to the admission of Indian pupils to their schools. It would therefore seem advisable to secure the Board's reaction to a joint building programme which would enable Indian pupils from the Masset Reserve to be enrolled in the Provincial School in Grades 4 and up. I do not feel that we should consider the expansion of the Masset Indian School to include junior high school grades when these may be enrolled in the Provincial school and I believe that we should approach the Board to see if at a later date we may increase the number of Indian pupils attending the Provincial school. I might add that in addition to the 25 pupils enrolled at the Masset Provincial School there are 27 pupils enrolled at residential schools. Even if it is possible to secure the admission of grades 4 and above to the Provincial school the number of school age pupils on the Masset Reserve will still warrant the employment of three teachers for grades 1 to 3 inclusive. R.F. Davey, Indian Affairs. Re: Teacher's Residence - Massett Your file 828-8 (F.1) With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of April 9th I have delayed replying with regard to a transfer of funds required to meet the cost of erection of the above mentioned building pending an opportunity of discussing with District School Inspector Davey our school construction program. Our whole program has been somewhat confused because of the fact that several buildings, construction of which was started last year, are to date uncompleted and we have yet to be advised of the cost of completing them, in addition to which no provision has been made in the Estimates for the erection of the school at Bella Bella. Re: Electric Power, Masset Teacherage We have for some time been negotiating with the Department of Transport for the provision of electric power to the new teacherage at Masset, but have to date delayed taking the matter up with you pending approval of that Department. We have now been advised that the arrangement is approved tentatively, subject to the execution of a formal agreement which will provide for the supply of electricity at 10¢ per kilowatt and at the same time relieve the Department of Transport of any obligation to supply power except when the plant is in operation for their own needs. Their plant is presently operating 16 hours a day, which period is ample for the requirements of the teacherage. The cost of bringing power from the nearest transformer to the teacherage is estimated at approximately $210.00 for material and labour and I would recommend that an expenditure of this amount be approved. The Masset teacherage, you will recall, is a modern building wired for electricity and it is felt that we should take advantage of the available power. We are informed by the local office of the Department of Transport that permission to connect to their transformer cannot be given until the formal agreement is drafted, approved and executed, but as this will entail considerable delay and inconvenience to the teachers would it be possible for you to contact the Department of Transport in Ottawa and to secure immediate consent to the connection to their transformer on the understanding that a formal agreement will be entered into at a later date. Re: Masset Teacherage Your File 828-8 (K1) You will note from Superintendent Findlay's letter of September 15th attached, that an additional amount of $305.00 will be required to entirely complete the above-mentioned building. Will you please have an accountable advance for this amount forwarded to Mr. Findlay. You will note his comments with regard to this prefabricated building. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Mr. W. S. Arneil Indian Commissioner for B. C. Federal Bldg. Vancouver, B. C. A credit voucher has been completed and forwarded to the Department, accounting for the expenditure of $3569.09 incurred on labor and cartage charges in connection with the erection of the Masset Teacherage up to the week ending August 27th. With the main part of the furnace reaching here on Sept. 3rd at the same time as the arrival of the teachers, it has been necessary for work to be carried on in the basement while the teachers were occupying the Residence. This work has not yet been completed since a further supply of furnace pipes is expected on Saturday next. As stated above the accountable advance for labour has been expended as of August 27th. Wages for the weeks ending Sept. 10th and for two days in this week are owing. This totals $145.00. With the remaining furnace work to be done a further $60.00 is required. I would therefore request that an advance of $205.00 be forwarded as soon as possible to cover these labor costs. This will allow the project to be completed. I may say that the residence is a very fine building and has become the show place of the vicinity. It is to be hoped that with such excellent accommodation and conveniences we may be able to hold teachers for longer than one term. J. A. During the Auditor's recent visit to the Quesen Charlotte Agency office, it was brought to his attention that two accounts with Kurt Lindner General Store were outstanding, and on making enquiries of Mr. Findlay, we learned that these were for materials supplied in September of last year for the Masset Teacher's residence, and further that although Mr. Findlay was aware that certain accounts with this Merchant were outstanding, he did not connect these with the accounts in question for the reason that, as explained in his letter of October 13th with enclosures, attached, he had prepared an explanatory letter and a voucher which apparently, however, never left his office. Mr. Findlay felt that the responsibility in this matter was entirely his and it was not reasonable to expect the Department to pay an account which had been outstanding for over a year, and for which the Department had no knowledge and consequently, he paid it himself. Although we appreciate Mr. Findlay's feelings in the matter, the expenditures covered by his Voucher No. 599 are legitimate charges against the Department and it is felt that Mr. Findlay should be re-imbursed. I have prepared a Purchase Order covering the two accounts and would recommend payment of the Voucher as submitted. W.S. Arnell, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Enc. -mo Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Federal Bldg., Vancouver, B.C. Dear Mr. Arneil: Further to our telephone conversation of yesterday, I am attaching a voucher to cover the two accounts concerned. As stated in my previous letter, these items were purchased during the final stages of completing the teachers' residence at Masset Reserve. The items were, in every respect, considered essential and I did not hesitate in purchasing them in order that the house might be completed on time. When the accounts were submitted in October a letter of explanation and a voucher covering the purchases were prepared. The usual procedure is, in cases other than routine vouchers, to prepare a rough draft of letter and voucher which is placed with the work to be completed. The fact that the extra copy of the account was filed still does not explain how or why the voucher and letter were mislaid. I can only presume that it went into the waste basket and was destroyed. I realize now that I should have noticed that I did not sign the completed letter or voucher, although with mail being sent out only every two weeks, everything is usually signed at one time. Mr. Lindner mentioned the account some months later, but I did not pay particular attention since he had been agitating for the payment of the old transportation account. The matter has worried me and my action in paying the account was taken due to the fact that I feel the responsibility rests entirely with me. I appreciate the fact that you feel I should not assume the responsibility for payment, but I believed my action was in the best interests of all concerned. It will most certainly be appreciated if the account is passed for payment, but this still does not detract from the fact that I feel the responsibility for the error very keenly. May I express my thanks for the consideration shown by you in the matter. J.A. Findlay, Indian Superintendent. Dear Sir: I have received a letter from Acting Indian Agent Phillips in which he refers to Inspector Barry's recommendations regarding vocational training in the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools. Mr. Phillips no doubt refers to the Inspector's reports on the Massett Indian Day School of May 28th, 1936, and May 17th, 1937, and to reports on the Skidegate Indian Day School of May 30, 1936, and May 15, 1937. It will be recalled that the Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools open on October 1st yearly and close on May 31st. The period during which vocational training might best be given in these schools is from November to March, inclusive. The Inspector has recommended that authority be given to Acting Indian Agent Phillips to arrange for instruction in vocational training at Massett and Skidegate Indian Day Schools at a sum not to exceed $100.00 at each school. Capt. Barry states that 50¢ per week for one lesson each week would be sufficient, and the total sum suggested to cover the salary of the two instructors, Boys' and Girls', at each school would be a little less than $50.00 for each school year. The remaining $50.00 of the sum suggested by the Inspector for each school would be used to cover the cost of the materials required. I concur in the recommendations of Inspector Barry in this connection, and would be glad to be advised if authority may be given to Acting Agent Phillips to make arrangements for such instruction in the two Day Schools of his Agency. Yours faithfully, D.M./AC R. A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. of Welfare & Training, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Day School dated May 12, 1938. Vocational Training: A small grant was authorized by the Department to pay for instruction in Basket Making and the carving of Totem Poles in the native slate. A start has been made in the Basket Making but so far it has not been found possible to do much with regard to the carving of Poles. I should like to see the third classroom, not at present used, fitted up as a Vocational Room. A Circulatory Heater to burn wood and costing about $40.00 would be required, also two large kitchen tables or better two tables made of dressed lumber and with movable trestle supports, and a Singer sewing machine. A few rough forms would also be needed, so that the children might sit at the tables. I would recommend that the grant for Basket Making and the grant for instruction in the carving of Totem Poles, which in each case covers the cost of materials, and does not exceed a total of $100.00 in all for the school be continued for another year, with the provision that definite results must be forthcoming by May 1939 if the grant is to be continued after that. I wish also to recommend the expenditure of not more than $15.00 on materials for the Sewing Class which I wish to see started at this school. The boys are not old enough for Manual Training at present. I have asked the teachers to give more attention to Arts and Crafts and Vocational Training at this school, and to take the necessary time from the academic studies. Later I believe that the academic work should only take half the day and the afternoons might well be devoted to Basket Making, Totem Pole Carving, Sewing and Making Dresses etc. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, B. C. Sir: I have to report as follows for the Queen Charlotte Agency for the month of November 1938. The average attendance for the Massett Indian day school was senior class 38.00 and the Junior class 38.43 at the Skidegate School the averages were Senior Class 19.52 the Junior Class 27.32. I was successful in securing Black Slate for use in the Vocational class for the making of Totem Poles etc. I have not yet secured the services of an Instructor to teach same, but hope to get this going in the near future. Dyes were given to both schools for use in basket making, these classes are proving to be very interesting to the pupils who look forward to the above work. B. T. Phillips, Acting Indian Agent. I am pleased to report that totem pole carving at the Massett school is in full swing, and on my visits inspected some of the work which is very good indeed. I gave a talk to both classes on the possibilities and future of totem pole carving and basketry, needle work is also being taken up, much interest being shown by the pupils. B. T. Phillips, Indian Agent. EDUCATION: Both the Massett and Skidegate Schools have been painted inside and outside, new wood shed, toilets, and urinal have been built (or nearly completed) at the Massett School. New wood shed and toilet have been built at the teachers' and new furniture and alterations for the comfort of our teachers. At the Skidegate Reserve a new animal is being built, and also a new fence is being built at the teachers'. There is no doubt that the Indian schools are the best on the Islands; the Indians children of this Agency are very bright, and several are now attending superior schools here, the children are exceptionally good at needle work, drawing, painting and very musical, the parents are very keen on giving their children a good education. We are not equipped for manual training, but have a large class room for this purpose at the Massett school as soon as conditions permit an instructor for that work. Basket making also Slate Totem pole Carving was taught at both schools, but this was stopped at the beginning of the war, several Indian drawings and designs have been entered in a competition at the Stanford University, U.S.A., we have not as yet heard the result of judges, I usually visit the Massett School three times a month and the Skidegate twice a month, Junior Red Cross work is being carried on at both schools. The Massett school has been adopted by the Sir James Barrie Imperial Daughters of the Empire, from which sporting goods etc. have been received for the pupils. H.E. Phillips, Indian Agent. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa. Re: Slate Deposit - Queen Charlotte Islands I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Findlay's letter of February 12th in response to a suggestion from this office that action should be taken to promote training in slate carving and other handicrafts at the Skidegate Indian Day School. You will recall that the Department purchased an area containing this slate or argillite deposit (reference Mr. MacInnes' letter of March 24th, 1941, file 27156-11), for the benefit of the Indians of the Skidegate Reserve with the object of ensuring that the deposit would not be commercialized and supplies would be always available to the Indians. It is apparent now that slate carving is fast becoming a lost art there being only a few older Indians carrying on the work at the present time. The cost of the proposal outlined by Mr. Findlay will not be great and I would recommend that the Department approve payment of $1.50 per hour for two hours a week instruction by one of the slate carvers mentioned by the Agent and that the Department authorize payment of an amount not exceeding $50.00 per annum for the slate material required. I would also recommend that favourable consideration be given to the Agent's suggestion that some instruction be given the girls in mat weaving and basketry during the period the boys are receiving instruction in slate carving. I would not recommend, however, that any instruction be given in silver craft work as this would likely conflict with the pupils other craft work and academic training. Consideration might be given to this instruction at a later date. (Signed) W.S. Arnell, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Riddoch Indian Agent Sir, I have received a communication from the Rev. A. Hall, missionary in charge of the station at Alert Bay, requesting me to lay before the Department the necessity of providing a day school at the Ma-ma-le-le-kalla Village, Village Island. Mr. Hall in his letter mentions the fact that there are two other Indian villages in close proximity to Ma-ma-le-le-kalla, and he has hopes that children from both these villages may be induced to attend the Day School. I find on referring to the last census taken that there are only seven children of school age at the Ma-ma-le-le-kalla Village, nine at the Ta-wak-teek Village, just opposite, and eight at the Kwa-wit-tis Village, which is quite five miles distant, making a total of twenty-four children. Of this number it is not likely that more than twelve would attend as I do not think that any of the children from the Kwa-wit-tis would be able to attend, on account of the distance. The children from the Ta-wak-teek Village at Ta-chi-ma-ka-mi could attend as it is not more than one and one half miles. A. W. Towell, Esq., Indian Superintendent. Sir, I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 23rd with regard to a request from the Lord Bishop of Columbia that a Day School be established on the Kamikamika Reserve. I have to advise you that I have gone into this matter with the Indians of the Kamikamika Band and I find that there are fourteen children under six and twenty children between six and fifteen years of age. Of these children a number are at present attending the Fort Bay Industrial School. There are enough children belonging to the Band to warrant a school being started. However I think it is only fair that I should let you see both sides of the situation. The Indians of the Kamikamika Band have a good village site, good buildings, but during probably seven months of the year the majority of them are wandering about in different places engaged in various occupations and it is not probable that there would be a very good attendance at school during those months when they are busy at their various occupations. It was brought to my attention that the Indians of the Taraktenk Band, who live about a mile and a quarter or a mile and a half away, and the Indians of the Kwautele and Matilai Band, who live about three miles away, would send their children by boat to school every day and take them away again after school was over. I am too well acquainted with the Indians to believe that this would last more than a few days at the beginning and an odd day afterwards so that no dependance could be placed on the attendance of any children from these other villages. The Kamakillikalla Indians have been asking for a school for several years past and it is on account of the fact that they do not remain steadily at the Village that I have not recommended it to the Department years ago. It might be worth the experiment but I would not like to give any guarantee that the school would be kept in operation regularly more than about five months out of the twelve. Dear Dr. Scott, You will perhaps recall that when you were in Victoria during the summer, I had an interview with you in Mr. Betchburn's office regarding a Field Matron or Teacher for the Indians settled in and around Village Island, and the parts east and north of Alert Bay. I have been discussing this matter with our Mr. Corker-missionary at Alert Bay—who knows the situation better than any one. He is of the opinion that there are numbers of children within reach of Village Island who will never be sent to the Boarding School, and who nevertheless require instruction and care. He feels also that unless there is some one at an out-lying point like Village Island the good work done at Alert Bay can never really tell because so many of the boys and girls fall back again for lack of friendly sympathy and support, soon after returning to conditions of the old life. In view of these facts I have approached our lady workers at Alert Bay. These ladies have felt all that I have written for some years; and they have been longing for an opportunity both to help the children who will not come to the boarding schools, and to conserve the fruits of the hard work done in those schools. To this end I am in a position to state that Miss Nixon—a member of our present staff at the Girls' Home, Alert Bay, and for many years our Teacher there—is ready to offer her services as Teacher of a day school at Village Island; and that Miss O'Brien, who has been working for me among the Indians at Alert Bay for upwards of two years in social work, would be ready to accompany Miss Nixon as Field Matron. In Miss Nixon's case, a salary would have to be provided; but Miss O'Brien would be ready to go for a nominal salary of say, $30 to $40 per month. The suggestion I would venture to offer is that... Wherever the school-house might be built, living accommodation should be provided for the ladies, perhaps overhead. Mr. Porter tells me that if the department would go ahead with the plan, the Indians on Village Island, who are very keen to secure a school—there are some 20 children there at present—have promised to help with the building without charge. I may add that I have had a talk with Mr. Mitchburn about this matter, and he states that he believes it is the right way of dealing with the situation, and that he will support the details as I have set them forth herein. While I am sorry to take away Miss Nixon and Miss O'Brien from Alert Bay—where they have both done excellent work—yet I am fully persuaded now that this suggestion of establishing an outpost is so vital to the whole work, and that only experienced workers among Indians will do, that I am ready to make the sacrifice, if the department listen to our combined judgement in the matter. We can more easily find workers for Alert Bay than for Village Island. Commending the whole enterprise to your favourable consideration, I remain, yours very truly, [Signature] Indian Affairs. Sir: On February the 21st, I visited a Settlement of Indians located on Village Island. This Island is about 15 miles from Alert Bay, B.C. I made this trip with Mr. Agent Halliday. In September last a Mission for the help of these people was opened by Miss Nixon who has been connected with the Alert Bay Girls' School over ten years, and Miss O'Brien who has been Field-Matron without salary in the village of Alert Bay for four or five years. The expense with this work so far has been paid by these ladies. In fact, when they called at my Office last August, they said they were not going to ask the Department for help at the present time. Miss Nixon is carrying on the school and has enrolled 19 pupils of school age. This is a very isolated spot. It will need two workers, and I am sure that if one of the present workers had to leave the other would not remain. It would be well, I think, to let the school go on as it has been going for the past six months. By that time, June the 30th, it will be known whether a new school is to be erected at Alert Bay or not. The best thing that can be done with these children is to enrol them in a Residential School. The Agent is sympathetic and has provided some requisites for the school. These ladies carry on religious services on Sunday. They teach the children to sing, and they are trying to inculcate the great principles of the Bible. The children are responsive to a marked degree. I may say that I was delighted to find the Village so clean and tidy. These Christian workers are reaching the parents through the children. A few of the children of this Village have attended the Residential Schools at Alert Bay. I will keep in touch with this movement through the Agent, Mr. Halliday. Your obedient Servant, R.H. Sir: This acknowledges the receipt of your letter of July the 23rd and No. 156-13-1 with regard to the application of His Lordship, the Bishop of Columbia, requesting the Department to allow salary for Miss Nixon the teacher and for Miss O'Brien the Field Matron. These ladies have been for the last year carrying on educational and evangelistic work among the Indians on the Mamalilikulla Reserve which is about 15 miles from Alert Bay. I reported on this work February 28, 1925. The Village is small for the services of two paid workers. There are nineteen pupils of School age enrolled. With this number of pupils the school work will justify the expenditure of the money necessary to make the school efficient. My recommendation, therefore, would be that as there is no assurance that the Alert Bay plant will be enlarged in the near future, provision should be made at once to carry on educational work on this Reserve. Then regarding the employment of a Field-Matron, I do not know whether there is an urgent need for a worker of this kind or not. With the Hospital at Alert Bay to deal with serious cases, I have doubt as to the need of such a worker. On the other hand it will be difficult to get one worker to remain with the work. Sir, The Department will doubtless remember that considerable correspondence has taken place regarding the institution of a school on Village Island Reserve for the benefit of the Indians of the Mamalilikulla Band and adjoining tribes. It has been more or less of an experiment but the attendance at the school has been so good and the success has been so great that I feel justified in asking the Department to consider building a school house on the Reserve for that purpose. Yesterday two of the Chiefs of the Mamalilikulla Band called to see me and they had a proposition to submit which I think is worthy of consideration. There is in the hands of the Department between $190.00 and $200.00 of money credited to that band for trespass of timber. They told me that at this meeting they had decided unanimously to ask the Department to use that money and to donate sufficient more money to buy material for the erection of a substantial school building 40 feet long and 26 feet wide, the building to be used as a school house and social hall as well as for church services. They also ask that a carpenter be sent to oversee the work and to help in the building and they themselves will supply the labor providing the material is on the ground at such times as they are there at home to do the work. They leave for the fishing some time about the middle of May and are away more or less continually until the middle of November so that during these months they would not be able to render any assistance in the building of the school. They seem very desirous of having the work carried on and the Indians themselves are very pleased with the results but there are so many children attending that the building they have at present will not hold them all and they come in relays to school. I would recommend that this assistance be given subject to the proviso that the building should be under the control of the Department for school purposes and could only be used for other things with the consent of the teacher who might be in charge at the time otherwise there would be a tendency to use it for feasting and other purposes which might be inimical to the work. It is so seldom that the Indians themselves are so enthusiastic over the education of their children that I think under the circumstances it would be a pity to disappoint them.
