Dear Mr. Williams: As promised in my note to you some weeks ago, I called at Village Island, while on my visit to Alert Bay, and went carefully into the matter of school affairs there. Since my return I have talked the whole subject through with both Inspector Barry and Commissioner Ditchburn. Inspector Barry has convinced me that the possibility of Miss Yeoman qualifying for teaching work is rather small, and I think I am prepared now to withdraw my advocacy of her appointment. The Commissioner, the Inspector and I have decided that we all ought to work together in this matter and secure a Church of England qualified teacher who will also be interested from the missionary point of view. I am not without hope, therefore, that we may be able to secure someone who will satisfy us all and fulfill the several points we are desirous of securing in this teacher. I trust it will not be long before we shall be ready to submit the name of a successor to Miss Nixon as teacher at Village Island. Another matter that we have been discussing together and which I understand Indian Agent Halliday has already written to you about is the question of a successor for Miss Dibben (as Miss Helen at Hur Bay). We are all agreed that since we are making this change, while Miss Dibben was as faithful and devoted a worker as could be found, we should try to secure these characteristics combined with a greater knowledge of nursing and better training in this art. The suggestion which I find we are all in favour of is that we should combine the nurse at the Industrial School with the Field Matron in the Village, if this meets with the Department's approval; and if we can also secure the consent of our own Church of England Commission dealing with these matters at Winnipeg. There are many considerations which commend this procedure. I think I should place first the growing sympathy that it ought to produce between the Village and the School. Then, the combining of the positions will enable us to pay a better salary without demanding more from either the Department or the Church Commission. Again, the dual position would mean a greater challenge to the right kind of nurse, and she would also have the companionship at meals, and other times, of a larger body of persons all interested together in this Indian work. I am writing at this time commending the matter to our own Commission and I hope your Department also will find it possible to agree in this method of filling the position. Looking forward to hearing from you again, I remain, Yours faithfully, Alert Bay, B.C., September 28, 1933. Sir, I am in receipt of your letter dated September 20 re the above. Mewham) A/Indian Agent The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Canada. The Village Island School seems satisfactory under the present arrangement, and I gather from Capt. Barry, School Inspector, good progress is being made, but unfortunately owing to the pot-lach activities in this particular portion of the Agency during the past winter, the attendance has not been as good as desired. However, a separate report has been made on this problem, and it is hoped with the plans we have in mind, that the Department will do all in their power to help solve this difficulty. The school at Village Island I understand is owned by the Church, but the Department are expected to pay for the running expenses and upkeep. I am under the opinion all day school buildings where we have the school definitely established should be taken over by the Department, and the title vested in the Crown as these buildings are all located on reserves. I am also of the opinion in the best interests of all concerned, our schools and arrangements for the education of Indian children should be slowly segregated so that the responsibility will eventually rest entirely with the Department. I understand the salary cheques of certain teachers in our schools come through the Columbia Coast Mission which would mean the teachers come more or less under their jurisdiction. I am merely drawing this to the Department's attention, realizing the fact at times when this arrangement exists certain pressure is brought upon the Department to undertake work which in our opinion is not practical or necessary. For this reason I feel if all the day schools were controlled entirely by the Department and arrangements made through this office, more efficiency would be the outcome and the administration less confusing. Sir, Under date of June 24th His Lordship Bishop Schofield of the Diocese of British Columbia, in a letter written to the Department, copy of which he forwarded this office for our information, recommended to the Department the appointment of Miss Bowden of 2312 Mark Street, Victoria, B.C., to succeed Miss Dora P. I have carefully perused His Lordship's letter, and do not altogether agree with some of the remarks he has made therein, in which he says, "One of the difficulties of Village Island has been to keep the children in good enough health to be regular at the school." Personally, I do not feel this is fair to the late Matron, Miss K.J. O'Brien, M.B.E., even though Miss O'Brien was not a fully qualified nurse; nevertheless her care of the Indian children at Village Island has been remarkable and very satisfactory indeed. Our difficulty in having the children attend this school regularly is through the fact quite a number of the families go trapping in the winter time as well as being late returning from the fishing grounds, together with potlatch activities which affect the school attendance. It is also noted in His Lordship's recommendation of Miss Bowden that she is a graduate of the Victoria Normal School with a second-class interim certificate which he states he is sure will be gladly rendered by the Department. His Lordship also mentions Miss Bowden is a fully qualified nurse, and that she is at present employed on the permanent staff of the Jubilee Hospital at Victoria, B.C. We feel with so many teachers carrying first-class certificates out of employment in British Columbia, it is hardly fair to appoint one who is now employed in the nursing profession to a position as teacher of this school where the term has always been somewhat short. However as it has been the Department's policy to be guided more or less by the Bishop's nomination, I do not wish to interfere as I realize it is a very type of person who will fit into this particular location. This nomination has been discussed with Mr. Phalen who only very recently visited this Agency, and it was decided to leave the matter entirely with the Department. I feel, however, it would be better in the future if nominations were forwarded through this office in order that we will be kept in touch with the progress being made in regard to appointments. Replying to your letter of January 27th last file #215-6-9952, I beg to advise you the question of opening the Mamalilikulla Indian Day School has been under consideration since last mid-summer. In your letter of August 28th last, file No. 215-6-6462, you stated the department felt that unless the number of children available to attend is much larger than during the last quarter the school was in operation, it is doubtful if it would be advisable to re-open this school. In view of this I immediately undertook a survey to find out how many pupils would be available to attend school and sought the co-operation and help of Miss K.J. O'Brien, M.B.E. We had three different conferences over this matter and as we were unable to find sufficient children, reporting the matter to you was delayed hoping that something might change the situation whereby sufficient children could be found and the school opened. In the meantime Miss Hanuse, now Mrs. David Dawson, got married, and when I approached her again about teaching school she informed me that she did not think she cared to. Recently Mrs. Lucy, who was Matron in charge of the Preventorium at Alert Bay, has moved to Village Island to make her home with Miss O'Brien and I understand that in order to find something to do she has undertaken to teach the four (4) or five (5) children who are in the village. A few days ago another family returned which will now make the attendance eight (8), I am given to understand, but this is all that will be attending so far as I can learn. I do not know what Mrs. Lucy's qualifications are as a teacher, but presume it would be better than having the school closed. If the department felt they could afford to open the school for eight (8) pupils and if Mrs. Lucy's services would be satisfactory and she would give us an undertaking to hold school regularly and that her work as teacher would come first before village nurse, I would be in favor of having her appointed to this school for the balance of the term; which could not be longer than May 31st, as the Indians will be leaving at that time. The whole situation is very unsatisfactory and it is regretted that the one or two families who live there with children are deprived of an opportunity to educate their children through other Indians choosing to live elsewhere rather than at home. RE: Mamalilikulla Indian Day School and Teacherage I have tried every conceivable means of finding a way in which Mamalilikulla Indian Day School can be opened for academic term 1949-50 with the amount of funds approved by the Department for repairs to temporary building for teacherage, and I find it impossible. The funds provided are not sufficient to repair the proposed building in order to make it livable in an isolated location such as Village Island. There are no conveniences of any kind, no plumbing or water in the building, and people are going to insist on having a bath once in a while. Should the Department approve of sufficient expenditure there is no one available now to make all these repairs in order to get the school opened at the beginning of the term. The confusion has arisen through the fact that School Inspector Davey, yourself and the writer did not examine the Bell home carefully when visiting the village. At that time we could not get a key to get into the building; otherwise, we would have known that it would have taken considerable money to complete the construction, and therefore in all probability would not have entertained the renting of that building. As you know I consulted Henry Bell immediately after to ascertain whether he would rent the building to the Department for a teacherage, with the understanding that he would finish the construction of the building, install plumbing and have the building ready for occupancy at the beginning of the school term. When I checked up ten days ago to find out how the work was progressing he informed me that he had not commenced the work and that he did not now have time and refused to give us any cooperation. It was at this stage I immediately went to Village Island to find out if there was any other building that could be used as a teacherage, and my long distance 'phone call to School Inspector Davey was the result of this trip. p.t.o. I have now come to the opinion that it is useless for us to try and open this school this year when we cannot find a proper place to accommodate the teacher. I am, therefore, recommending that this school not be opened this year due to circumstances beyond our control. At the present time school supplies have been ordered and no doubt are in transit. These are being shipped in-care-of this office and will be received and put in storage here until the new school is built. We have also submitted a requisition for a new oil-burning heater for this school. As it has not been ordered by this office would you please cancel this requisition dated July 9th, 1949. We have no further commitments other than the Department has forwarded this office an accountable cheque in the amount of $105.00, which was to be used for rent for the building we originally proposed to rent from Mr. Henry Bell. This money will be returned to Ottawa once the decision is concurred in by your office and School Inspector Davey not to open the school this term. I regret having to inform you that I cannot find it possible to open this school for the reasons given above, as I was most anxious to have this school opened; particularly when School Inspector Davey was able to obtain the services of a teacher whose Mother would be able to accompany him to this isolated place. Reviewing this particular school situation a little further, it now seems to me we have two alternatives: We should consider the erecting of the new school and teacherage at an early date so that any funds spent in connection with this school will be of a permanent nature, or the Department be prepared to spend sufficient funds (approximately $400.00 in addition to the $200.00 for the purchase of the building) on the Church building which would make it livable until we could get the new school and teacherage built. If the Department wished, some of the necessary funds could be used from the Welfare Vote, as the building will be given to an Indian when no longer required by the Department. If some plan along this line could be worked out, it is possible the school might be opened later this fall when we are able to obtain help to have the necessary repairs completed to the building. Sir: I have to inform you that it has been decided to allow Miss M. Nixon, teacher at Village Island (Kumalililikulla) salary of $75 per teaching month for the period this school is in operation during the present school year. Sir: I have to inform you that His Lordship Bishop Schofield has nominated the services of Miss Patricia Grimmond as teacher of the Namalilikulla (Village Island) Indian Day School for the coming school year. Sir: I have to refer you to official letter of the 24th ultimo, regarding the appointment of Miss Patricia Grimmond as teacher of the Namalilikulla (Village Island) Indian Day School. His Lordship Bishop Schofield now informs the Department that Miss Grimmond has decided that she cannot accept the position, and he nominates Miss Dora White, 401 Henry St., Victoria West, B.C., for the position. He states that he consulted Mr. Inspector Barry and that he approves of the appointment of Miss White. The Department is informing His Lordship that approval is granted for the appointment of Miss White for the coming school year, to begin duties on or about September 1st, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month. I have to request that you will give her every assistance you can in her work at this school, where it is hoped she will meet with success. Your obedient servant, A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary. W. W. Sir- Enclosed please find Quarterly school Return of the Indian Day School at Village Island for the quarter ended March 31st. I would like to make a few comments on the remarks of Miss White re her reasons for the school being closed. Miss White spent her Christmas holidays at Alert Bay and the weather was so bad it was not possible for her to return to her school in time. This was known to me at the time and in order to get her back when she did, it was necessary that I send the Departmental boat to Village Island for this purpose. I would like to refer also to the date of March 19th when Miss White states most of the village were at Alert Bay where some of the people were confirmed. This is quite true, as His Lordship Bishop Schofield was at Alert Bay and practically all the children of Village Island were here being confirmed by him, and I presume Miss White did not think it necessary to hold school with one or two children only. I trust this explains the matter fully to the Department and that they will forward her cheque without any undue delay. I am also enclosing a Requisition for School Material which I would recommend be forwarded her. Your obedient servant, (M. S. I have looked up her quarterly returns, and find that the school started on the 1st of November and that she has taught two full months, and believe the cheque should have been for the full amount and no deductions made. I did note, however, that Miss Bowden when filling in her quarterly returns, stated that school opened on the 2nd. Sir, Under date of February 13th last I wrote the Department explaining Miss Hughima Bowden, teacher of the Namalilikulla Indian Day School, had made an error in her last quarterly return by stating the school reopened on November 2nd instead of on November 1st, and that a deduction of $3.00 had been made from her November salary cheque on that account. December 9th, 1933 Mr. Harper Reed, Indian Agent, Telegraph Creek, B.C. Dear Mr. Reed, I am herewith sending you the McDames' School Requisition List for next summer. I hope it will not be found to be too heavy. After much waiting I got a letter from the Ex-Ministry of Lands in Victoria stating that I could have a parcel of land at Liard Post, one acre, as a lease, $5.00 a year for 29 years. The Bishop thinks it is not worth it, so I am hereby asking the Indian Department through your Office the permission to erect a log building on the Indian Reserve at Liard Post, at a place near Watson's Cabin, as soon as conditions will allow. We had a foot of snow around the 15th of October but it all melted away soon after, then it rained like the flood. The roads and even the C.W.R. line were in an awfull shape up to a week ago. On the other hand the weather has been easy on the wood pile. But it looks as if we were in for the winter now. Hoping it is not too hard on you. With kind personal regards for the coming season, I remain, Yours very sincerely, Two Subjects: McDames Creek. School Supplies. Liard Post. establishment of Mission Building. E. Allard & Co., M.I. Sir, I beg to submit, herewith, a letter received from the Rev. Father E. Allard, C.M.I., who is and has been in charge of all R.C. Mission work in this part of the Stikine Agency. He has already established a Church in the Townsite of Telegraph Creek, which is his Headquarters. He has constructed a small log Cabin, which is used as a Church, on the Dease Lake Reserve, at Dease Lake, which is 150Km on route to the Interior. At Mc Dames Creek, the centre of the Cassiar District, he has established quite a large Church combined as a R.C. Mission School also. (RG 10, Volume 6403, File 830-1, part 1) PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA Extract from letter dated July 27th, 1938, from Indian Agent Harper Reed, original on file 160-5: Liard Post, B.C. As the Department fully knows this location is to say the least of the matter - a trouble spot. Even this year whilst Bishop Coudret was down that day, another bad break out of drunkenness took place. This attracts all the Indians who can come from other Posts, and this summer they all congregated here. Therefore, his Lordship saw many Indians and many children, mostly of the McDames district. Really there are very few Indian children located at this spot, who can be stated as Liard Indians. At the time the McDames School was started, Father Allard was in charge, that was about 8 years ago. After the building was three parts finished Father Allard turned his attention to Liard Post, at the end of each summer. Then the white men who were married to Indian women requested to have a school started and offered to build and help same along, Watson, LeCormier and Hazelburg being the prime movers. Father Allard on this obtained a plot of ground outside the Reserve, and matters were started up. But no help was given and matters took on the coating that the Indian Department should do all this, and that it was their business to do so. After the R.C.M.P. Detachment had been moved away, much drunkenness came about, and it has been going on ever since. This in itself has induced many more Indian families to spend their summers at Liard Post. However, it was decided by the R.C. Missions to build a Church at Liard Post on their own compound, and this they have accomplished. His Lordship stated that here would be a very fine place to establish a winter school. This office would rather not say as to if this would be a success or not. It can be seen that there would be trouble ahead, for Liard Post is only 6 miles south of the Yukon Boundary Line and nearly all the real Liard Post Indians are really Yukon trappers. It can be seen that most of the Indian families would at once request Relief, they would not trap for a living but would trap for luxuries only. The cost would be great at this remote location. and it would certainly draw Indian families from other points, in fact McDames Creek Indians would no doubt go to Liard Post. Another point to be considered is that of law and order; it is hopeless to try and do anything down there until some detachment of Police is allowed. Again - the Edmonton Air Plane Mail Service has just established base on Watson's Lake, a very suitable point 30 miles within the Yukon, and it is now understood that Mr. Watson is running a store. If this is so, and it will be checked later on in the season, Liard Post as it is today, will go back to just a small trading spot, a meeting place of the Dease River and the Liard River proper. The matter seems to be a real problem at the present time but will be looked into and reported upon when the summer's visit to here has been completed. From the office point of view all these schools must be taken in conjunction with the Indians' trapping affairs - otherwise it results into a mere question of rations and relief. One thing is certain - if the Nomads give up or do not use their trapping grounds they will be entirely lost to the Indians in the near future. Memorandum: Re: Proposed school at Liard Post. Right Reverend E. H. Bunoz, O.M.I., Prince Rupert, B.C., visited the Department today in connection with the above school. You will remember the correspondence on file and you will also note the Bishop's letter in which he stated that he could not obtain any assistance from the Provincial Government for the education of the half breeds. The Bishop's argument is that even though the Provincial Government did not do anything for the half breeds that this did not constitute a reason for our doing nothing for the Indians. However, the Bishop stated that he recently had an interview with the Minister of Education for British Columbia, Honourable Mr. Weir, with regard to this matter and Mr. Weir stated that he expected to visit Ottawa in the near future and promised the Bishop to discuss the matter with us. If a school were established it would be attended by approximately 10 half breed children and about 15 Indian children. I promised the Bishop that I would bring the matter to your attention again and that even though the Provincial Government did not act we would give the matter further consideration when preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40. It is interesting to note that the Bishop states that Liard Post is on the regular route of the mail plane which flies from Edmonton, Alberta, to White Horse, Yukon. The plane lands at Liard Post to take on or discharge passengers. If not stopping they drop the mail in passing. Consequently, this place has regular mail service throughout the year. Skilled Watcher Can Detect Slight Differences in Types Stilt Sandpiper and Lesser Yellowlegs Resemble Each Other Greatly In a recent edition mention was made of the Stilt Sandpiper and its resemblance to the Lesser Yellowlegs. Despite the similarity of color, the two are such distinct personalities that often a glance is sufficient to distinguish them. As it flies, the Stilt Sandpiper carries its bill aimed down at an angle between the vertical and horizontal. The Yellowlegs holds it between 45 degrees and the horizontal. It will raise its wings and plunge its head down beneath the surface if necessary, to procure mud or other food, and of course once it has done so it drags its tail sticks up at a greater angle than the latter's. Immature Marsh Hawk Immature Marsh Hawks are shifting for themselves, and become a regular part of the marsh and woodland scene. As they fly back and forth, turning and banking, you see the white rump patch and the rusty-brown back. They are not exactly like either parent, but they resemble the female. Where she is gray-brown with streaks there are more orangish-brown with less contrast across breast. Very few adults are in evidence, the proportion of the young to the old is probably very large. Such analysis shows that the most common small mammal, the shore-birds almost invariably fly up in silence when one passes by, for in silence they do not hear them. They can capture small birds when they can capture them, and we can appreciate them. Sandpipers are much as did gunners of 50 years ago. Piloted Woodpecker Large In the woods across the country we have the Piloted Woodpecker. Better known as the pileated woodpecker (crow size) it is fairly frequently seen. It is all black and white except for the red crest. The male is scarlet, in the female only the top half is scarlet, the rest being brown. The male has a metallic wine-colored moustache mark; the female a black one. The Piloted Woodpecker is the largest of the Flicker family, and much louder, and their sharpness makes them ring across the distance in a way which the smaller flicker never can. Member of Second Category Guides at Wilson Creek Camp By JOCYNN SADLER Second Category Guide Wilson Creek Camp A little party would love this. Girl Guides a lovely place. The Vancouver Guides have said it might be reached by a second-class trip up the beach road stopping to load at summer station. On the wish it might have gold in and touch three lakes and five camp sites within a forest. I wish but why wait? If I was living here instead of visiting, I'm liking the Idlewild Camp. We have at our own disposal a big log hut. And like this, I expect I'd enjoy the friendly camp life, and a shower by the sea, and the "cruising ship." And that I'd even wish for some rain. We had at the Johnstone River camp, near the south district at Coldstream, a big log hut where we slept in the bay barn when the camp was flooded. That was nice. For you can't have a down here unless it is a log hut at Wilson Creek, and they've got them for seven weeks. Everything is dry except it is smoky from the fires. It was wonderful to experience a change in surroundings. We came to Vancouver by train, connected with the West Pacific, and here I am in Canada, in a little section of this vast country. Wilson Creek Girl Guides have been given to them by the Stage Lumber Company. They are at the old log hut, there are three and a T.O.D., and there is a big cabin with a big rock fireplace at one end where we have our fires. It is a big log hut and is a memorial to Con. Mrs. Brown who was the first president of a plane. There are five camp sites at each end of the hut. There are eight patrol tents in residence, with each little camp site having a separate tent allotted. There is lovely clear water for the camp is along the river. It is a wonderful place, company, for I really feel belonging to the West Pacific. Our camp is now in for evening gathering at Brock House with other camps and for some activities. There isn't a moment's time here. There's something interesting going on. Miss Pruden, the captain, is always about herself into someone's cache in and stole its provisions without notice. Stikine Agency Atlin, B.C., March 18th, 1939. Sir: I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of February 1939. During the fore part of this month the R.C. Mission's general affairs came up for reporting upon and some with their school requirements for next summer were duly submitted. Since then letters have been received from His Lordship Bishop Coudert, O.M.I., to say that he is flying around to all the Mission points in the month of March, and expects to meet your agent in Atlin about the end of March. It is quite possible that he shall return to Telegraph Creek on the same plane when all matters will be most closely taken up with him. They are pushing out their Mission to such an extent, that it is seen many requests will be coming along for further aid with their schools and their various teachers, and it is considered that some idea should be given to the Department as to what they intend to do - ere it is done. An instance in point is that of Teslin Lake in the Yukon at which point the better set of Indians come in from the B.C. side of the Provincial Line. Here Bishop Geddis of the English Church has maintained a very fine school, to which all the Indian children attend, and to which the Department has allowed much help. To-day the R.C. Missions have taken up some vacant ground around the Trading Post of Messrs Taylor & Brown, and last summer moved Father Brein up from the Post and started to build their own Mission. Now the Indians of Teslin Lake have quite a Revenue to spend, and being Indians are ever ready to shift their attention to something new, especially if they are made a lot of in so doing. Therefore some little "rumpus" might be expected at that point in the near future, but of course nothing much can be done about the matter. Most of these Indians did at one time belong to the Russian faith, and that with the stated fact, that the English Church has had in its keeping, for some years now, quite a sum of money belonging to the Indians that was collected for a new school, or Church, and that same has never been built. The matter is just mentioned for future reference, as going by experience gained on the Yukon River, many years ago; such affairs blow up sometimes into serious matters causing much trouble and expense. However after an interview with Bishop Coudert, more information will be gained, which will be submitted in due course. Harper Reed, Indian Agent. Ottawa, March 3, 1939. Dear Sir: I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th ultimo with reference to the school that was conducted at Liard Post during the past summer. I note your recommendation that the Department provide a salary for the coming summer for the teacher of this school. No provision for such expenditure was made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40. However, as we are not making any grant for the salary of a teacher at Dease Lake it has been decided to allow an amount of $100.00 a month for 3½ months for the teacher at Liard Post during the summer of 1939. It should be distinctly understood with those in charge of the school that in so far as the Indians are concerned all Indian children must be told on September 15 that they are not expected to attend school after that date. This understanding will carry out your plan that the parents should not be hindered from leaving for the trapping ground at the proper season of the year. You should consult Rt. Rev. E. M. Bunoz with a view to having him nominate the teacher. I enclose staff questionnaire which you should have completed and returned to the Department when Bishop Bunoz advises you of the name of the teacher who will be in charge of the school during the summer of 1939. The supplies that you requested for this school are being ordered from the Government Stationery Office. Yours truly, Harper Reed, Esq., Indian Agent, Telegraph Creek, B. C. Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6403, File 830-1, part 1) Sir, Re: Liard Post, B.C. - Summer School, R.C. Mission. I beg to submit herewith a Requisition for school supplies that are necessary to carry on the school work at that point, in charge of Father Poulett & Father Allard, in Stikine or the R.C. Missions. Last summer we allowed some supplies and with the attached list, they will be well fixed. Much correspondence has passed in regard to the establishment of a school at this point. The whole matter was in abeyance for some time on account of the fact that the white men who had half-breed families promised to start a school for the R.C. Missions, but when the time came to do so, turned the matter down. They were not exactly to blame for such action, for the R.C. Mission did not continue its steady attention to that area, owing to the death of the late Father Allard, and then when the situation which had again taken in hand, it was found that the half-breed families were not residing at Liard Post any longer in the summer time. The fact was that the airplane were giving attention to the home locations of their white traders & trappers, and they had no reason to reside at Liard Post. Also much trouble has been met with at this Post with single men white traders, much disorder has come about and up to now very no proper or steady police control has been allowed by the B.C. Provincial Police. This has caused another Indian family to come to Liard Post during the summer time. Therefore today we have more Indian youngsters than ever we have had, and of course few half-breeds. During all this time the R.C. Mission has built up a church and a school house on their own Compound, and on which no grant has been used received from the Department. Last summer as the Indians children were around the Post, the late Fathers there, started a day-school for the Indian youngsters, but no Teachers salary was allowed. Last summer also the whole affair was looked over, and it is now considered that the Fathers should be paid some amount for their work at school teaching. After some talk they thought that a winter school would be much better than a summer school. If this year's rent does not agree, for the simple reason that were not started, the families would not go out to the trading grounds, no revenue would be obtained, "utensils would have to be allowed - and a general "winter-school" come about. All these Indians are wild nomad and should get out trapping during the winter months. It is respectfully suggested that the Department consider the allowance of a Salary for a Teacher during the summer Months only. The period should be three & a half months i.e., June-July - August - Half September. The rate of pay might be the same as that of Mr James (i.e., $110-00 per month). The Teacher will no doubt be most needed, but when considered that sum is really very good, as they more or less, live off the country. Also of course he would be allowed school supplies. The building is their own and not on a R serve, and the whites down there should help along all further expenses. The reason why the month of September is cut in half, is to allow the trapping families to arrange their "provisos" or jaw-bone with the stores and get ready to go out. If the school is continued up to the last minute, the Indians will hang on and only crowd up on trapping grounds not far distant. A distinct line should be drawn and the Mission instructed to close down the school for Indians congregated at a certain date. If partly dry at that time, anyone will still allow to attend, then the "travellers" will still hang on around that fact. The Fathers say "John Good Ton" when seen last fall, and certainly a school is needed here during the summer time. The fact that there is no Law & Order here at present is entirely a matter outside the school and must receive attention, in its right course. Therefore may the necessary authority be granted for a Teachers Salary at this point, and His Lordship Bishop Dunno be advised that this grant is being allowed. I am, Sir, Your obedient servant. However at this day school the matter of sanitation is stressed, and every child attending has to wash his hands etc., for which we have supplied paper towels, and soap ere he enters the school-room, and this is regularly adhered to. I beg to submit a Report on the non-operation of the above Seasonal School covering the summer of 1940. Under Authority 158-6-1 May 21st 1940, permission was granted to open up this school for a term of three months. Rev Father Poulet C.M.I. was to have taken charge with a Salary of $1000.00 per month. School supplies and some more equipment was kindly allowed, and sent down, but the Indian families refused to come in to the Post and live. Several reasons are given for this. Firstly that there was an epidemic of influenza just at the time the school should have opened, and the Indians stayed in the bush. Secondly that the Indians cannot stay around the Post, and live on store food, as they would have to do, on account of the scarcity of Moose and Fish. Thirdly, a reason known to the Indian Office mostly, is that the "Whites" have of recent years been coming into this country, mostly from Fort Nelson way, and the Indians are really not wanted around Liard Post. Over many years now, it has been reported that our Indians down there are being "crowded" and that fur resources were being "gobbled-up". To-day a very jumpy state of affairs exists, and the Indians having no areas set aside for them in the Yukon, and little or no protection, are more nomadic than ever. This Fall several Yukon Families have come down the Liard River, passing Liard Post and gone trapping down the River from that point. The B.C. Game Department are responsible for a whole lot of this movement, they have pushed trappers up from Fort Nelson, and those that are not permitted to trap in B.C., have been encouraged to move along into the Yukon. In all matters are in a state of "flux". There are five Indian Reserves set aside for our Nomadic Indians at Liard Post-these are for the Yukon and B.C. families. Yet, knowing this, a new Game Warden stationed at Mc Dames Creek and calls at Liard Post quotes:- Sect.15 of the B.C. Game Act-viz -An Indian unless he is a resident shall not hunt or kill game in the Province at any time. In this way he causes a paralytic effect to take place on The R.C. Mission School, and the resting of Indians on those Reserves. A case in point is that of Dan Loots whose family have always rosted at Liard Post, living on a Reserve there. Because this Indian runs a trapline up into the Yukon, he is marked "out" by the B.C. Authorities as a Yukon Indian. Others who are treated as Yukon Families are not able to shoot feed around Liard Post which is situated under 6 full miles from the Yukon - B.C. Boundary Line. As stated above, lately the Fur Returns have been less and less, and unless the Indian produces fur, he is not wanted around a Trading Post, where White trappers will be met with. There always was a rough white element around this Post, and it seems today that they have banded together to have the Indians remain away off in the bush. The five Reserves at this point are valuable, and there seems to be some idea that if the Reserves were not there, a very good Air Field could be created, and "prosperity" be established for all inhabitants concerned. Therefore it is considered that an Indian School at Liard Post will continue to meet with misfortune, and hardships of no ending. There seems to be three ways in which schooling to our Wards could be accomplished, and they are as follows: That the Teacher should go out to the Indian Camps, wherever they are during the summer time, or remove the site of teaching to the Indian Camp at Fish Lakes, about 40 miles S.E., along the Fort Nelson Trail. Here Moose and fish will be obtainable for many years to come. Secondly:- That the Indian Department supplies Rations etc to the families who do reside on the Liard Post Reserves, and will send their children to the present school. This is much desired by the R.C. Mission, but as can be well understood would be much abused when put into force; and result in much disorder as between the rough white trapper and the Indian Families. We have had too much of this at that point, up to the present. Thirdly:- That the R.C. Mission be told to concentrate their efforts, in all ways, towards making, once again; the Mc Dames Creek Post their Main Headquarters, and so getting the Indian Families to congregate at this point for their summer visits to the trading Post. Perhaps it would be possible to issue some Rations to the families whose youngsters attend school at this point, in an effort to keep them away from Liard Post, itself. An attempt will be made to call on Father Poulet this winter on way to the Atlin Winter Inspection, when his views will be obtained; it having been impossible to visit this point during the past summer. From every view-point of common sense, there is no doubt but what a R.C.M.P. Constable should be stationed at Liard Post, there is a back area of the Yukon here, that requires some real attention today. However should the B.C. Authorities have the power to stop our Nomads "Hunting & Fishing" in B.C. during the summers, it is not quite known what events will come about as about half our Indian Families down that way, do go over the northern boundary line of B.C. during their winter wanderings. I am, Sir, The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Dept Mines & Resources. OTTAWA. Harper Reed Indian Agent. Your Reverence, A year-end talk on R.C. Lower Post Summer Day School We were amazed to hear that the new Acting Indian Agent of the Stikine Agency had no knowledge of a summer day school being conducted at Lower Post until he arrived there by boat in June; if the gentleman had only perused his files, he would, no doubt, have seen many letters referring to the summer day school at Lower Post; and since no official announcement of its closing had been given to him, and no new teacher appointed, it was self evident that both school and teacher were being maintained; at any rate, if he had entertained in his mind any doubt on the matter, surely he could have written to us and inquired. As you may know from past reports the conduct of the day school at Lower Post has been fraught, all along, with great difficulties, on account of the very primitive and nomadic spirit of the Indians calling at that post, and who are probably the most backward Indians of North America. The various war undertakings carried on in that part of the country this summer have still added to the ordinary difficulties; the excitement of the children on seeing so many white men with their strange and noisy machinery, and the various war works which their parents were called upon to perform in widely scattered areas away from the school, made the attendance of the children more unsatisfactory than ever; and so little encouragement did Father P. Poulet, the school teacher, receive from the local Acting Agent, at the occasion of his visit, that he decided right there and then to follow the latter's suggestion and stop the school altogether. We hope, however, that Father P. Poulet, O.M.I., will be compensated over and above for the work he has done during a full month previous to your Agent's visit. Telegraph Creek, B.C. Jan.22, 1943. Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources. Referring to Department letter of October 14 last to Bishop Joudert regarding the Lower Post Indian Summer school which was operated from June 8th to about July 7th, 1942, I am submitting herewith a return as instructed. The records in this office indicate that this school is private and as such does not come under the ordinary provisions of Indian Day Schools. No word was received from the Church officials prior to the opening of the school that it was their intention to operate, nor was any nomination of teacher submitted. The school was briefly reported on in the July monthly report for this Agency. It was visited July 3rd and the attendance was only six although several times that number of children was available. The teacher complained that he was quite discouraged and did not think he would continue the school much longer. As a matter of fact the teacher was not giving his full time and energy to operating the school as he was employed by the U.S. Engineering Department carrying freight and passengers down the Liard River with his boat. If conditions amongst the Indians at Lower Post remain the same next year I cannot recommend that this school be re-opened. The Indian parents show a distinct lack of interest in the school although the reason for this attitude is not easily discernable. These people are at Lower Post so short a time (3 months at the most) and regard it as a holiday time that it is felt the children reflect their parents' attitude and dislike being tied down by school and the parents do not try very hard to make their children attend. Unless the attendance is very regular the short school term does little or no good as the children forget in the nine months they are away from school most of what they learned during the short term. In view of this it is considered very questionable whether the expense of teacher is warranted. The results of the teaching are so far poor. Enc. Indian Affairs. Dear Mr.Phelan; I found your letter of March 13 here upon returning from a long trip on snow shoes.I tried in vain to reach Ross River where one of our fathers is isolated since last September;I was unable to get through on account of the heavy snow on the summit of the mountain ranges and on account of the extremely mild weather;after four days of fruitless attempt and hard going,my guide and I had to turn back;we were one full week on the trail,unable to cover more than 12 to 15 miles a day. Father Desmarais who has been at Ross River since last Summer is conduc- ting a school at that point for some 15 indian children,but I am absolu- tely unable to give you any detailed information,on account of the comple- te lack of communication with that point since last fall.When he returns here next summer I will send you all the particulars concerning this new school. I wish to thank you for the raise in the salary of our teachers;$135.00 is quite a sum and will be a great help to them;I would have preferred by far,however,to have their transportation granted by airplane to such a place as Klappan or Cariboo Hide,as it has always been in the past a source of great friction between the mission and the Agency. Those are the only places where the use of plane is almost an absolute necessity;later on,if the school is approved for Ross River,the latter point also should be serviced by plane,though communication by water or overland between Whitehorse and Ross River can be had during the summer months,which is not the case for Klappan nor Cariboo Hide.-I am fairly well acquainted with Western Canada and a good part of the arctic,and I can say that,to my knowledge,there is no place so hard to reach as Klappan or Cariboo Hide.I defy any Official from Ottawa or any other Inspector of the Branch to get to those points otherwise than by air. Reverend Sir: I wish to acknowledge your letter of January 28. I am sorry I wasn't able to send a reply to you by the last plane, February 15, but completely swamped with work which accumulated during my absence in January. I am enclosing the copy of a letter I wrote to Father Carpentier, who I presumed was in charge of the Mission, clearly indicating my attitude towards the plane charter to Klappan, including the offer of 1/3 contribution towards the cost of the charter. In view of the remarks in your letter concerning about the blame upon the undersigned for the arrangements made by Father Forget with the pilot for the trip to Klappan, I wish to state that I certainly did not make any arrangement with Pilot Callison, or anyone else, for the trip to Klappan. When I received word from Father Carpentier in late December to the effect that Father Forget had ignored the offer made in my letter of December 19, and was chartering the plane himself, I had nothing further to do with the arrangements. I understand that Father Forget himself telegraphed the Northern Airways asking them to fly out to Klappan, and this fact can easily be checked. Father Forget did not reply to my letter of December 19 and this fact is ample proof of his lack of interest in my offer. Another point which you have misunderstood is evident in the 9th paragraph of your letter. You stated I gave you the impression Father Forget might still hesitate to go even though I had offered to pay part of the charter. My remark to you was that I was afraid unless you wired Father Forget not to charter the plane himself he would do so. My remark was made in response to your statement that your Mission couldn't possibly pay for the charter. I also told you at that time that although Father Forget had ignored my offer to pay 1/3 the cost, the offer still stood if you wanted to accept it. cont. Concerning the 8th paragraph of your letter I am quite sure I informed you that I had absolutely no authority to charter an aircraft for moving school supplies out to Klappan, even though the nurse accompanied. As you know, in the past the school supplies have been carried by dog-sled and horse pack, and the trips I have made personally have also been by dog-sled, the cost being considerably less than half that of the plane. I repeat here that unless it had been for the possibility of combining a charter with the teacher, such a plan would not have been entertained for it does not give me, or the nurse, enough time to do all the work that it required on an infrequent visit such as the one to Klappan. In the face of the misunderstanding which this matter has caused, and which it appears is due principally to the attitude of Father Forget, I think your plan of forwarding the data to Ottawa for settling is the wisest course. I certainly can do no more than make good the offer to pay one third of the trip, but if my Department feels obligated to pay more they will instruct me. I am enclosing a cheque for the $43.00 deposited in the Agency office as part of the cost of the trip, and I also enclose a letter addressed to Father Forget from the Northern Airways which I am led to believe contains the account for the trip. In conclusion I would say that if the salary for Klappan School is $800.00 as indicated in the letter of even date accompanying this one, I feel that it will take care of any extra expense entailed in getting out to the school, along with the offered 1/3 cost of charter, which will amount to approximately $75.00 if the Northern Airways refuses to reduce the amount they have charged. Dear Father Carpentier: As you probably know, Father Forget interviewed me last evening about air transportation to Iskut Lake, and in view of the difference of opinion which arose between us I feel it wise to place the whole thing on record and explain my reasons for the action I took. There has been unnecessary misunderstanding over this matter and I would not wish it to interfere with our cordial relations. I could see Father Forget was somewhat upset last night, and I am sure if he had stayed to discuss his problem amicably we could have arrived at a partial solution. First I would like to correct some erroneous opinions which Father Forget held: (1) That this Department had planned to charter the plane to go to Iskut Lakes. (2) That I had definitely committed this Department to sharing the cost of such a charter. In regard to (1), I certainly had no intention of chartering the plane, and did not give anyone the opinion that such would be the case. Father Forget first approached me about the matter and told me that the Mission would perhaps have to fly the supplies out to Klappan School. At that time I suggested that if it could be arranged and was convenient to the Mission, Miss Humm and myself might share the trip. It should be remembered that at that time I had no word from Bishop Coudert regarding a proposed trip to Caribou Hide with stop over at Iskut Lakes on the return trip. Regarding point (2); at no time in our tentative plans did I tell Father Forget definitely that we would make the trip regardless of other circumstances. However, up until I received word from Bishop Coudert by Mr. Herman Peterson on December 15, I certainly planned on going out to Iskut Lake if there was room in the plane. Then I learned that Bishop Coudert wished to share the charter to Caribou Hide, and was planning to stop off at Iskut Lakes on the return, I quite naturally changed... changed my plans about going out in January. The Department would not authorize the expense of both trips. They would be within two months of each other. When you told me the other night that your load for the plane wouldn't leave space for the nurse and myself, and that you could use the space for taking out additional supplies to assist your making the trip to Caribou Ride by dog-sled, I quite naturally concluded that you were satisfied with the way things had worked out. At least you certainly gave me no reason for thinking otherwise. However, Father Forget last night endeavoured to place the responsibility upon me for letting you down badly. He told me that you certainly wouldn't be able to charter the plane without this Department sharing the expense, and implied that the only reason you considered flying supplies out was because the nurse and myself wished to go, and would pay part of the cost. This is not in accordance with what you expressed when we discussed the matter the other night, and I find it a little hard to understand. I have a proposal to make which you may wish to consider: Miss Dunn is anxious to visit the Indians at Iskut Lake, and Dougeen Dennis has asked for some rations, therefore it is suggested that if you will allow us space for 300 lbs., this Department will share the cost of the trip on a comparative weight basis. This would work out to this Department paying approximately 1/3 of the cost of the charter. The 300 lbs. will be made up as follows: Miss Dunn, approx. 150 Nurses equipment 30 Cod liver oil 30 Rations 70 School scribblers 20 300 lbs. If you wish to carry out the trip under these arrangements, please let me know as soon as possible. Yours very truly, H. S. Sampson, Indian Agent. Rev. C. Carpentier, O.M.I., In Charge, R.C. Jan 16 Aircraft Charter Telegraph Creek-Iskut & return 2 hours 40 minutes @ $35.00 per hour 226.66 (Carrying Nurse and Priest) Dear Bishop Coudert; I am writing this letter from Carcross on my way to Atlin. In discussing the charter trip made by Father Forget to Iskut Lake I learned from the Northern Airways that Father Forget had notified the pilot, Pat Callison, that the Indian Affairs Branch was paying 2/3 of the cost. I do not know what Father Forget would tell the pilot that for, because as you know, my offer was to pay 1/3 the cost. My offer was based upon the weight of our respective loads. The load which this Department had originally arranged to send out was: - Nurse Dunn: 150 - Medical supplies: 50 - School books & tools: 50 - Rations for Indians: 150 but I am informed that we did not actually have that weight. The total load taken by Mr. Callison was 1200 lbs which means that out of that total probably 850 lbs. was Father Forget's load. Under these circumstances, and considering too that Father Forget had previously obstinately refused to take up my offer of 1/3 cost, and stated he was chartering the plane himself and didn't wish the assistance of my office, I certainly can not consider asking the Department to pay for 2/3 of the cost. I also learn from the Northern Airways that the cost of the charter will be about $225.00, as it took them 2½ hours flying to get into the lake. Bad weather made them turn back on their first attempt after they had got within about ten miles of their destination. Then, on the final trip to Telegraph Creek they found the area around the town fogged in and had to return to Buckley Lake for two hours to wait until it cleared. Personally I do not think that the Northern Airways Company should expect you to pay for all that flying time when the complete trip under normal conditions would have taken 1½ hours at the very most. I would therefore suggest that you take this up with... Mr. George Simmons when he returns. When you arrive at an understanding with Mr. Simmons I would suggest that you bill this office for a third of the cost arrived at and I will submit the account to the Department for payment. I think it would be advisable for me to go on record as stating that in no sense was this airplane charter requisitioned by this office. It was originally Father Forget's idea, and has remained his responsibility. If Father Forget had not been going out that way I would not have entertained the idea of flying the nurse and supplies out there under any other than emergency conditions. I have already had advice from the Department in this respect, and have been instructed. Yours very truly, R.H.S. Sampson, Indian Agent. Bishop J.L. Coudert, O.M.I., P.O. Box 95, Whitehorse, Y.T. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines and Resources, Ottawa. I beg to acknowledge the Department's letter of March 13, file 158-6-1, concerning assistance to school teachers proceeding to seasonal schools in this agency. It appears that the Department's letter is the result of the Rt. Rev. Bishop Coudeurt's representation concerning an aircraft charter which Father Forget of Telegraph Creek ordered, and I am therefore stating as briefly as possible, the circumstances of this case and submitting the account for the Department's decision as to what portion should be paid by them. The factors in this matter which may assist the Department to arrive at a decision are: (1) Last fall Father Forget mentioned briefly that they would probably be taking their supplies (food etc.) out to Klappan seasonal school by plane. (2) The undersigned then stated that if it could be arranged the nurse and himself would accompany and share the expense as an assistance to the school teacher, or Mission, but neither then or subsequently did Father Forget ask for any definite commitment, or state his definite intentions. (3) On December 15 word came from Bishop Coudeurt that he was anxious to share a charter to Caribou Hide, stopping off at Klappan on the return journey. (4) In view of the Bishop's request it was pointless for the undersigned and the nurse to make two trips close to each other, so the senior missionary, Father Carpentier, was informed that we would not be able to share the trip if they still intended flying their supplies out to Klappan. Father Carpentier replied that it would work out for the best for the Mission as there was enough supplies to take out to load the plane, without any additional extra weight. (5) Nurse Dunn was informed of this by the undersigned, and also that she would be prepared to make the trip to Caribou Hide and Klappan with the Bishop, a few weeks later. (6) Father Forget, the appointed teacher for Klappan, visited the undersigned December 18th and said he would not be able to charter the plane unless this Department assisted. It was explained that a duplication of our work at such a cost was not warranted and that we therefore couldn't make the trip. (7) On reconsidering the matter it was felt that the nurse could accomplish a good deal by two trips so a letter was written to the senior missionary offering to pay one third the cost, estimated at about $50.00 if we could have space for 300 lbs. (8) This offer received no acknowledgement so on December 29th the undersigned went personally to visit the Mission to obtain their answer. Father Forget was absent, but Father Arpentier replied that when given the letter, Father Forget remarked that he was having nothing to do with the offer, and that he was chartering the plane himself. (9) January 3rd, Father Forget interviewed the pilot of the aircraft which arrived that day and chartered the ship for January 15th, to fly out to Klappan school with supplies. He also informed the Northern Airways agent at Telegraph Creek that he was undertaking the charter unassisted and that Nurse Dunn was going as his guest. (10) Bishop Coudert was interviewed in Whitehorse January 5th and informed of the situation. He told the undersigned that the Mission couldn't possibly pay for such a trip without assistance, so was informed that unless he wired Father Forget not to charter the latter would be making the trip. There has been some lengthy correspondence from Bishop Coudert over this matter since it occurred and he has endeavored to place the blame on this office for chartering the plane, although we had absolutely nothing to do with it. This latter point has been explained to the Bishop but he persists in his claim that two thirds of the cost should be paid by this Department. Rather than enter into further controversy with Bishop Coudert over this account, it is forwarded to the Department, together with copies of letters from this office concerning the matter, for their decision. Under ordinary circumstances the thought of chartering a plane to take either the undersigned or the nurse to Klappan would not be entertained because it does not allow any time in which to carry on our work as the plane will not wait for more than an hour or two. The trip by dog-sled is 60 miles, or 2½ days travelling, and has always been made by that means, both by previous school teachers and the undersigned, as it is not a particularly arduous or lengthy one. If the Department wishes to have all the correspondence on our files about this matter it will be sent upon request, but it is not enclosed now as it is somewhat lengthy and would consume considerable time to cover. Dear Sirs: We the undersigned chief and members of Lower Post Indian Band strongly protest and repudiate the following quotation or article seventh of the letter written July seventeenth at the request of Mr. Simpson, Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek: "we would also like the school to be a government school. Some of us feel that the religious schools waste too much time in learning religion. We do not know this from experience, but some people who have been to religious schools tell us that they would rather have gone to government school, where they have regular teachers, and use all their time learning school work." This quotation represents Mr. Simpson's view only, who has always shown bigotry against Catholicism. We do not approve of it. At the time it was presented to us we did not understand its full meaning; but now we desire to advise the honorable Members of the Committee that we strongly protest against any representatives to the Government making reports against our Catholic Schools. We were all brought up as Catholics and we do not want to change our religion. So therefore we want all our children to be taught by Catholic teachers. We also want the residential school, if any be granted, to be under the care of the Catholic Church. Neary Superintendent of Education Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa, Ont. Dear Sir: I acknowledge the receipt of the check of $486.00 as salary for teaching at the Lower Post day school. I want to thank you for your particular attention in sending this check without delay. The school reports have been sent at the end of each month to our Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, but in case you have not as yet received these reports you will find a copy of them here enclosed. His Excellency Bishop Jean-Louis Coudert O.M.I. is telling me that you would like to have some information on our activities in Shesley last winter. Father J.M. Mouchet O.M.I. and I left Telegraph Creek by trail on January 22, 1948, for Shesley where we arrived on the 24th. Our plans were first to repair and readjust the B.C. Telegraph building to be suitable for a school, after which we wanted to teach school to the few children in the camp. To repair the house, both of us had to work 24 days, from January 25 to February the 21st. This work which, to my opinion, should have been done and paid by the Indian Department, was made at our own expenses; by our expenses here I mean especially our time since as for material we had to take what we had already on the spot. To note again that this extra work was done for the sole purpose of opening a convenient school during fall 1948. In case you would like to have details on the work done, here are the major repairs involved: we had to take out the kitchen floor in order to renew the rotten joists; we took down a whole partition and made a smaller bed-room in order to have the main room bigger and brighter by the addition of another window; we then had to repair a very bad corner of the room as well as the ceiling. After completion of the improvements, the Indians were so enthusiastic about them that they were anxious to come in good number the next fall for the opening of the school. They expected then to have from 14 to 15 children ready for school this fall, though I had no contact with them since last spring, I am positive that there will be enough children at Shesley this fall for the opening of another school-term. As all this work left us free for only the last week of February, I then taught school to the only six children in the camp. His Excellency Bishop Coudert O.M.I. came to visit the population during the first week of March and we then went back to... Telegraph Creek where other duties were calling us. I went into rather long details, sir, so that you could see by yourself what we are trying to do for our dear Indians often at the cost of many sacrifices and hardships. Hoping that this letter will please you and help you in your cooperation with us, I remain Sincerely yours, [Signature] Rev. Father Edmond Turcotte O.M.I. "Seasonal Schools. Lower Post Indian Seasonal School With regard to the Superintendent of Education letter dated March 5th last regarding the re-opening of the above named seasonal school during the forthcoming summer months the following is submitted for your information. This school was last in session during the period June 6th to August 17th inclusive 1949. At that time, sixteen pupils were enrolled at commencement with a final enrollment during the month of August amounting to eleven. Of this number enrolled, nine were of white status, either half-breed or enfranchised Indians who were permitted to attend as at that time there were no other school facilities at this point. Since August 1949 however, a new one room provincial public school is now in operation at Lower Post where the above mentioned children can attend during the academic school year and those few natives totalling six whose homes are permanently located within the immediate Lower Post vicinity are also currently enrolled. During the period June to September a number of nomadic Indian families make their summer camp across the Liard River from Lower Post proper. For the most part it is the intention of this office to see that the applicable school age children of these families are enrolled this year in the New Lower Post Residential School eliminating possible future hardships during the lean winter months when children are located in isolated bush camps and not accessible, for the greater part of the year, to educational facilities. (RG 10, Volume 6403, File 830-4, part 1) PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA Lower Post, B.C. via Watson Lake, Yukon June 2nd, 1948 Superintendent of Education Indian Affairs Branch Department of Mines & Resources Ottawa. Dear Sir: You will find here enclosed a requisition list for school material for the term which opened on the first of June. This material has been sent for last August, 1947, but has not been delivered yet. If you would be kind enough to see to it that the required material be sent as quickly as possible, we would be very thankful. The New Monthly Day School return book has not been sent either. And finally we have in our school files only few no. or Vol. 1 of Indian School Bulletin. We should appreciate very much to have Vol 2 complete. This requisition could not be sent any sooner because I arrived here just for the opening of the school; I do not send the present through our Indian Agent Office to prevent delay, since all the material is needed right now. Thanking you for your service and interest in our schools, I remain truly yours, F. Edmond Lurene O.M.I., B.A. June 16, 1948. Mr. R.H.S. Sampson, Superintendent, Indian Agency, Telegraph Creek, B.C. We have received a letter from Reverend F.E. Turenne in which he states that he opened the Lower Post School on the first instant. He states that there are no supplies in the school. Our records show that supplies for this school were ordered on December 3, 1947 from the Government Stationery Office and were to be shipped as follows: The Teacher, Lower Post R.C. Day School, Post Office - Watson Lake Express Office - Whitehorse. We also forwarded another requisition to the Stationery Office on March 9th. The supplies ordered on this requisition were addressed to you - see our letter of March 9th, 1948. As we received no reply to that letter we presumed that the supplies reached you. Please arrange for their immediate delivery to the Lower Post School so that the work at that school will not be unduly hindered. Bernard F. Neary Superintendent of Education. PP/MGD MEMORANDUM June 25, 1948. To: Superintendent, Stikine Agency. From: District Inspector of Indian Schools. Re: School Supplies, Lower Post Seasonal School. I refer to the letter of Mr. Phelan, dated June 16, 1948, concerning the supplies for the above mentioned school. I cannot understand the statement of Father Turenne that "there are no supplies in the school". When I visited the school several shortages were noted but the school was quite capable of operating. I drew the Reverend Father's attention to a number of articles which should be requisitioned and he made no reference to his failure to receive supplies previously requisitioned. His chief concern appeared to be janitor's supplies which were urgently required. These I asked you to purchase locally to save time. I also drew his attention to requirements in the way of texts and asked him to requisition these in the normal way as they could not be secured before the end of the present term in any case. R. F. Davey, District Inspector of Indian Schools. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa. Dept. file 158-6-1 (E.1) With reference to the Department's enquiry of June 16, wherein they inform that Rev. Turenne reports there were no supplies at the Lower Post School, attached hereto is a memorandum from Mr. R.F. Davey, District School Inspector, who visited Lower Post Seasonal School June 16th. Rev. Turenne was interviewed by the undersigned June 14th, but apart from mentioning that a few items of the previous year's requisition had not been received, there was no discussion, or complaint of there being no supplies at the school. It was suggested to Father Turenne that possibly the cause for some items being short was the difficulty in obtaining them. At that interview Father Turenne mentioned also that he had written to the Department drawing the shortages to their attention. The supplies for Lower Post school did not come to this office. Letter of March 19th last from this office recommended that supplies for this school be shipped directly to Lower Post, and it is presumed that is how they were shipped. R.H.S. Sampson, Supt., Stikine Indian Agency. Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa. With further reference to the Department's letter of June 16th, file 158-6-1 (E.1) and my reply of June 26th, I have to advise that a package of school supplies addressed to the undersigned at Telegraph Creek and marked for the Lower Post School has just been received. The package weighs 67 lbs. No doubt these are the supplies which Father Tureene expected. These supplies are being forwarded by express on the first boat leaving here and should reach Lower Post School about middle of July. Reference is made again to my letter of March 19th, which recommended supplies for Lower Post school be sent direct to: The Teacher, Lower Post School, Lower Post, B.C. Apparently this suggestion was overlooked and this has caused considerable delay. (Sgd) R.H.S. Sampson, Supt. Stikine Agency. It is bright and clean, and the children are well dressed and clean for the most part. The short term which this school operates, (about two months) makes it very difficult to achieve much progress as the pupils are away for ten months, but at least they are under some discipline and gaining some knowledge. Attendance is always a problem at this school on account of difficulty crossing the Liard River. Several Indian families live on the south side of the river while the school is on the north. It is a fast stream and a motor boat is required to cross without losing too much ground. The parents use this as an excuse for non-attendance frequently. The school is remote from headquarters and therefore no assistance can be given the teacher in increasing the attendance. Agency Stikine Indian Affairs. Sir, In company with Mr. Indian Agent Perry and at his request I visited Metlakatla School on April 29th. (only a short time ago I reported on this school). We found only three small children present although I saw a dozen of school age playing in the village. The school is steadily declining, and Miss Jackson, after years of faithful work, seems to have lost control. I would respectfully recommend that the Department take up the question with His Lordship Bishop De Vernet, of obtaining a new teacher for the school before next winter. As I understand she wishes to have a holiday, so it may be possible to arrange for a new teacher without weakening her unduly, after years of service. I have the honor to remain Your obedient servant H.E. Green Inspector. Ottawa, May 29, 1912. Rev. Now, I would like to add (not explain) that having been a constant & trained teacher for forty years (except for 1914-19) & in the dept employ as teacher for 15 years, I have never failed to send my forms in expeditiously & promptly. That is a part of my training & teaching. Obvious on however where I have been employed, there may have been a delay, as there has been no mailing facilities, & only boats have been able to make Rupert when seas have been calm or fairly calm. Authorities do not seem to realize our helplessness at times; however efficient & conscientious one may be. Yours truly, B. Shearman Prince Rupert, B.C., March 6th, 1944. REPORT ON SKEENA RIVER AGCY. Dear Sir: With reference to the vacancy for a teacher at the Metlakatla Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, I may say that I have interviewed this afternoon Miss Norma Francis Fullerton, 446 Marmont Road, New Westminster, B.C., a candidate for the above position. Miss Fullerton is a member of the Church of England and is twenty-two years of age. She received her elementary education in Alberta and some two years of high school work in New Westminster where she also took a further years commercial training. On completion of her education she taught for one year in commercial school. Miss Fullerton's brother, who was with the Royal Air Force, was killed overseas a few weeks ago and the girl is anxious to go to Metlakatla. She has expressed herself to me as perfectly prepared to live alone. Inspector Barry, after a somewhat lengthy interview with Miss Fullerton, considers that she might well be appointed teacher of the Metlakatla Indian Day School on a temporary basis for five months as from January 1, 1942. It will be remembered that this school ordinarily operates on an eight month basis from October 1st to May 31st yearly. Captain Barry arranged to give Miss Fullerton the necessary professional guidance to enable her to carry on the academic work at the above named school at least for the present. Miss Klippert was engaged on January 14th. The charge, therefore, is for services at $75.00 per month for 3½ months. I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, Indian Agent. The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont. Ottawa, April 26, 1913. Sir: I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a voucher for $262.50, salary of Miss S. Klippert, teacher of the Netlakantla Day School to the end of April. The quarterly return received from this school for the quarter ended March 31st last shows that Miss Klippert began duty on February 24th and taught only 24 days during that quarter. A cheque for $105.00, being the amount of salary due for that period has been sent to you for transmission to the teacher. As the quarters end on March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31, respectively, in each year, the salary due Miss Klippert for the month of April will be paid upon the receipt of her quarterly return for the quarter ended June 30. Your obedient servant, [Signature] Asst. Deputy and Secretary, Chas. Perry, Esq., Indian Agent, Netlakantla, B.C. With reference to your favor No. 118547-3, of the 29th ultimo, touching the matter of Miss Klippert's salary to the end of April, I beg to point out the following facts: On account of the dearth of teachers and consequent great demand for qualified persons, it was necessary for me to secure a teacher from a long distance. Miss Klippert was engaged by me on January 14th last, and she left Nanaimo for the north (a distance of seven hundred miles) on Monday the 17th February. In the meantime, arrangements had to be made for Miss Klippert's accommodation in Metlakatla. My family all being away at the time, it was not possible to have Miss Klippert at the agency. Rooms had to be secured from an Indian in the reserve and painted, and furnished with the necessary furnishings. This all took time. Then Miss Klippert had to make her own arrangements before leaving for the north, as she had come from Ontario to visit friends in the west, and did not expect to receive a call to Metlakatla Indian day school so far away. She having the best of references, and in consequence of favourable impressions I received as to her promise for useful service as a teacher, I deemed it wise to retain her trusting that the Department on being made aware of the facts would be disposed to recognize her services as a teacher as having begun from the time of her engagement, or at least from the time Miss Klippert left Nanaimo. With these facts in view, I would suggest that the Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Ont. be good enough to re-consider the question of remuneration in Miss Klippert's behalf, and if it is found possible to pay her the amount mentioned in the original voucher which I submitted, or at least a larger portion of it than has already been paid, Miss Klippert will be greatly obliged. I may say, however, in my own interest that at the time I appointed Miss Klippert with the approval of the Department, I did not pledge my word to Miss Klippert that she would be paid from the time of her engagement, but that I would endeavour to secure the Department's favourable consideration to special considerations under all circumstances. I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, [Signature] Indian Agent. Province of B.C.
