(RG 10, Volume 6403, File 831-3, part 1) Public Archives Archives Publiques Canada Sir, I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of Miss Winestone's cheque, no. 1375, for her salary as teacher of the Gitlakaditz Indian Day School for the June Quarter, amounting to $270.00, also Miss McCarthy's cheque no. 1222, for $208.50, for her services as teacher of the Wetlikatla Indian Day School, for same quarter. As both these teachers are receiving the same rate of salary and their schools were closed on the 15th of June, I cannot understand why there should be such a difference in the amounts of their respective cheques for the June quarter. The fact that the schools were closed before the end of the quarter was not the fault of the teachers, but because there were no more children in the villages to attend school, all having left to accompany their parents to the canneries, as the fishing season commenced on the 20th of June. I would respectfully point out that the deductions in salaries on this account is a hardship which the teachers do not deserve, as they are prepared to keep their respective schools open to the end of the Quarter if there are children in the villages. A deduction in salary according to the time lost is to be expected when a teacher opens school after the commencement of the term, but it seems unfair to make a deduction when schools have to be closed owing to absence of pupils. It is becoming increasingly difficult to obtain teachers in these out of the way places, largely owing to the enforced isolation and other inconveniences which have to be put up with, and I feel that to deduct part of their salaries through no fault of theirs, adds to the difficulty the Department has in retaining the services of experienced school teachers. I would strongly recommend that salaries be paid in full for each quarter excepting in cases where the teacher herself fails to commence her work at the beginning of the term or absents herself during the term without reason. As Miss McCarthy has asked why her June quarter salary was so low and as I am myself unable to explain or understand why there should be such a difference in the amounts of salary of Miss Winstone and Miss McCarthy, I would be glad to be advised on the subject. Your obedient servant, Indian Agent. The Assistant Deputy and Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa. Sir: I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, regarding the salary paid Miss McCarthy, Teacher of the Metlakatla Indian Day School, for the June quarter, last, as compared with that paid Miss Winstone, Teacher of the Gitladamicks Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that the return received from Miss McCarthy showed that the school was closed on the 15th of June, also on several days during the quarter. Full particulars were not given as to the reasons. Miss McCarthy began duties on February 12th; she taught 35 days in the March quarter and 45 days in the June quarter. However, in view of your explanation of the reasons for the closing of the school on the 15th of June, the Department has agreed to allow her full salary for the quarter. A cheque for $67.50, being the balance due, is being sent, as well as a cheque for $15, being bonus for month of June. The teacher should state, on the return, the reasons for closing the school on other than the regular date. I would point out that there are 200 teaching days in the school year, and it is expected that, unless circumstances prevent, teachers will conduct classes the full period, in order to draw the full yearly salary. Your obedient servant, Russell T. Ferrier, Supt. of Indian Education. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian agent, Prince Rupert, B. C. Memorandum: REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY Re: Metlakatla Indian Day School No. 831 In my memorandum of September 3, 1941, I advised you of the resignation of Miss Marjorie Bird. To succeed her the Department has appointed Miss Norma Francis Fullerton at a salary of $65.00 a teaching month plus bonus. I am advised that Miss Fullerton began duties on January 15, 1942, and she should be paid from that date until May 31, 1942. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the other forms will be forwarded to you as soon as received. I also attach Miss Fullerton's application for war savings certificates. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division. Ottawa, February 10, 1945. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 70, Vancouver, B. C. In a letter dated the 3rd instant Indian Agent Gillett advised that the Reverend B. Shearman died at Prince Rupert on the 2nd instant. It would be appreciated if you would consult Bishop Rix with a view to having him nominate another teacher for the Metlakatla School. In your letter of August 9, 1944, you recommended that in the event of a change of teacher being made at this school the salary be increased to $95.00 a teaching month, plus bonus. We are willing to allow payment at this rate for the new teacher. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division. Ottawa, March 18, 1945. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Box 70, Vancouver, B.C. With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, the Department approves the temporary appointment, for the balance of the academic year, of Miss Grace Wishart as teacher of the Metlakatla Indian Day School. As mentioned in official letter of February 10, salary will be allowed her at the rate of $35.00 a teaching month. You should have her complete and return the usual forms as soon as possible. Acting Director. Ottawa, August 14, 1946. Sir: I have your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the few minor repairs, including painting of the classroom floor and replacing of shingles blown from the bell tower and gable end of the Metlakatla Indian Day School, and giving an estimate of the cost of the material and labour. In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding approximately $32 in having the floor painted and the shingles replaced on the bell tower and gable end of the school. You should arrange for the purchase of any materials required and for the labour. After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. This work should be completed before the school reopens after the present summer holidays. Your obedient servant, A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C. Sir: In reply to your communication of the 8th inst. relative to repairs to the toilet of the Metlakatla Indian Day School, as recommended by Capt. Barry, I would state that the present structure can be repaired and a new pit dug for the sum of £30.00. To construct a new and larger building would cost approximately £75.00. I would recommend repairs to the present toilet. The school building is in need of repairs and painting, and any extra money available should be spent on the main building. Dear Sir: In official letter of June 29th last, you were authorized to incur an expenditure not exceeding $220 in painting and reshingling the roof of the Metlakatla Indian Day School. If there was any expenditure, accounts should be forwarded at once, in order to reach here before the end of March. Please let me hear from you as soon as possible in regard to this matter. Yours truly, A. F. MacKenzie, Secretary. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C. Sir: I beg to acknowledge receipt of the Department's letter dated Mar.14th relative to the sum of $220.00 authorized for reshingling Metlakatla Indian Day School last year. In reply I would state that the work was not done owing to the fact that there were no Indians able to do the work in the village last summer, the able-bodied having gone out fishing, and the past winter has been so stormy it was not considered advisable to have the work done. I regret this very much as the building is in need of both reshingling and painting. The money authorized was for shingling only. I am hoping to have the necessary work put in hand as soon after Easter as possible and shall be glad to have the money again authorized for this purpose so that there may be no further delay. Your obedient servant, Indian Agent The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa. Ottawa, April 1, 1936. Area: Outside walls and gables 3,500 Sq.Ft. gables shingled. Weather beaten surface, two coats paint necessary. 8 gals. white paint @ 4.75 38.00 3 " Shingle stain @ 2.50 7.50 1 " Turps. 1.25 1 lb. Filler 1.00 2 Flat paint brushes @ 1.75 3.50 8 lbs 2½" nails @ 20¢ .80 Scaffolding 4 pcs.12 x 2 x 12 - 96 feet. 6.00 Transportation, Prince Rupert to Metlakatla 7.00 Labor 60.00 $125.00 Dear Sir: The sum of $125.00 was placed in this year's estimates to cover the cost of labor and material required to paint the exterior of the Metlakatla Indian Day School. The need for painting the school was brought to the attention of the Department in a communication from this office dated June 15th, 1925, but the work was not authorized. In the meantime, the building has deteriorated rapidly, and painting to preserve the exterior walls should be carried out this summer. I am attaching herewith, detailed estimate of the cost of material required. It is proposed to purchase the necessary material locally, and the work will be done by Indian labor. I would strongly urge that this work be authorized as the building is beginning to look very dilapidated. Yours faithfully, W.E. Collison Indian Agent The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa. Dear Sir:- The attached application from Indian Agent Collison for authority to expend $125.00 to paint the exterior of the Metlakatla Indian Day School is recommended for favourable consideration. Dear Sir: With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, you may expend an amount not exceeding $125.00 in painting the exterior of the Metlakatla Indian Day School. It is understood that this amount will cover both material and labour. Yours truly, Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B. C. Dear Sir: The Department finds it necessary to return your voucher No. 9206. In your letter of June 28, 1938, requesting authority for painting the Metlakatla school you stated that the work would be done by Indian labour. Under these circumstances it is difficult to understand why you submit a voucher in favour of C. P. Ryan. If Ryan paid the others who were working it will be necessary to attach receipts from those employed acknowledging that they received payment for their work. In any case you should show the number of hours and the rate per hour. Yours truly, R. A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare & Training. W. E. Collison, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B. C. (RG 10, Volume 6403, File 831-5, part 4) Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa. Re the attached school requisition from Miss C. Merrett, teacher of the Metlakatla Indian Day School, this school was inspected recently by the Agent. There is no doubt that the supplies requested are urgently required. The present teacher's desk is in very poor shape and is an old fashioned table with one drawer. If the Department has funds available from this year's vote a new one could be bought and moved later into the proposed new Day School at this village. The pupils' tables and chairs are required for class project work. The tables can be purchased locally from the War Assets Corporation for $3.50 a piece and the chairs at $1.00 a piece, plus delivery charges from the War Assets Corporation warehouse to the dock and transporting to Metlakatla by gas boat. If the Department so instructs these will be purchased locally and they would prove an asset to the equipment of this School. The balance of the requisition will, of course, be filled from the D.P.P.S. F. Earl Anfield, Indian Agent. Ottawa, 31 December 1946. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Re your 215-8-6955 of March 28th, 1947, re the Metlakatla Indian Day School and teacherage, it is not considered advisable to make any attempt to repair the school as this building should be torn down. The teacherage can be repaired and made more habitable by completing the shingling of the roof and painting the entire roof. I made a careful examination of the house yesterday and it is recommended that the kitchen be painted and the living room and dining room be lined with Donnaconda board. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver. Re: Metlakatla School. Further to my letter of even date re action taken in regard to the above-noted Day School. I recently went over to Pillsbury Cove and inspected two loxstave buildings 60 x 24 each. These buildings were purchased by the Metlakatla Indians when the camps were turned over to this Department at the close of the war. The owners of the two buildings, both of which are in first class condition, offer to return them to the Department for their purchase price of $50.00 a piece if the Department will use them to build a school at Metlakatla. There is sufficient material in these two buildings to erect a two room school building suitable for the needs of Metlakatla for many years to come. I realize from correspondence to hand that funds are limited under the Educational Vote, but if provision can be made, it would seem advantageous in every way to get this School erected this winter. On receipt of your advice I will get firm bids from reliable firms for the job. Prince Rupert, B.C. November 26th, 1947. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver. Re: Metlakatla Day School. On Saturday morning, November 15th, 1947, the Day School building was inspected in conjunction with the Council and found to be in a very dangerous condition. On Tuesday, November 18th, I went over this building again with a competent construction man from Prince Rupert, Mr. Roy Wicks, who confirmed my opinion and that of the Council that the building was unsafe for the use of children as a school. The foundations are rotten and the building is in process of collapse at both ends. The walls are bulging out and the floor has a bad slope. Both end walls are sinking into the ground. In view of these findings, a Council was held and I informed them that the school was closed. After considerable discussion an arrangement was reached whereby the Church Army Hall could be rented for $25.00 a month. The School was moved into this Hall and is now operating there. It is requested that the action taken be confirmed as to closing the School and the renting of the Church Army Hall at stated rate as from November 18th. Authority is also requested to purchase glass and putty for this building at a cost of $9.80. Authority is also requested to submit wage sheets for $37.80 for labor of seven men engaged for 56 hrs. @ 67½¢ an hour to move the entire effects of the school to the Church Army Hall, including installation of blackboards, setting up of stove, moving desks, cupboards, stock, fuel and all supplies, also glazing broken windows. The situation was considered of an emergency nature and the action taken had in mind the need of continuation of studies of the pupils who are making splendid progress under a very capable teacher. Only one school day was lost in the whole transaction. Miss Merrett was consulted throughout and she agreed that an immediate change was essential. In fact, once she really saw the condition of the building, stated she was not prepared to continue teaching therein for another day. The Department's instructions will be appreciated. F. Earl Anfield, Indian Agent. Ottawa, December 8, 1947. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C. We have your letter of the 4th instant, file 12-11-1, with reference to the condition of the Metlakatla Day School. It is noted that it has been necessary to make arrangements to abandon the school and rent the church army hall. We will allow a rental at the rate of $25.00 a month for the latter building effective from November 18th, 1947. The Department will also pay the expenses of $37.50 which were incurred in transferring the school furnishings from the old school to the church army hall. You do not make any comment on Mr. Anfield's letter of November 26th with reference to purchasing two logstave buildings. If necessary to pay for these buildings at the present time, we could find the amount of $100, at which amount the Agent states they can be purchased. The moving of them and the making of necessary repairs in order to have them suitable for our purposes as a day school will have to be delayed until the next fiscal year when funds will be available. Please let me have your recommendation in the matter. Bernard F. Neary Supt. of Welfare & Training. PP/MGD Indian Affairs Branch; Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa. Re: Metlakatla Indian Day School I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of November 26th from which you will note that following examination of the above-mentioned school building it was found to be in such a dangerous condition that further occupancy was unwise. You will also note that the Agent has entered into an arrangement covering rental of the church army hall at the rate of $25.00 a month. The school was moved into this building and is now operating there. Although it is regretted that the dangerous condition of this building was not the subject of a report at an earlier date the action taken by Mr. Anfield was no doubt warranted and the arrangement is recommended for approval. I would also recommend that the Department approve an expenditure of £37.80 for transferring the school furnishings to the church army hall and re-installing them there. I do not feel however that the Department should be called upon to meet the cost of repairing the building as the rental asked is, in my opinion, sufficient to take care of these repairs. Payment of the cost of glass and putty for the building by the Department is not recommended. D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C -mh enc.
